posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
This is THE GREATEST SINGLE PLAYER MODULE EVER!! I know I am biased, but screw it, it's worth the fuss. It's a well-balanced mid-high magic SP module with a GREAT STORYLINE, AWESOME tilesets, and it has a really cool thing, which is that as you move forward through the story, your revisit areas and meet again with a couple of NPCs that you came in contact with during your early days and the whole area is just different, and the people as well, everything has moved on with time. It uses Tony K's AI, EMS and CEP enhancements to create THE ULTIMATE SP experience. It's available at the NWvault and has one of the highest ratings of all time!

You can download it from:

The Aielund Saga Act I - Nature Abhors a Vacuum
The Aielund Saga Act II - Defender of the Crown
The Aielund Saga Act III - Return of the Ironlord
The Aielund Saga Act IV - The Fall of Aielund Pt1
The Aielund Saga Act IV - The Fall of Aielund Pt2
The Aielund Saga Act IV - The Fall of Aielund Pt3

Enjoy!

posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content: Personally, I'd avoid using the EMS altogether. It's too poorly a document overhaul of the whole magic and not so magic system for my tastes (I want to know exactly how the altered game works) with some changes being of debatable worth. It's anyhow a possibility given by the EMS author to turn it off by using the "fake" EMS hak file, so no real harm was done.

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
KailPendragon wrote:Personally, I'd avoid using the EMS altogether. It's too poorly a document overhaul of the whole magic and not so magic system for my tastes (I want to know exactly how the altered game works) with some changes being of debatable worth. It's anyhow a possibility given by the EMS author to turn it off by using the "fake" EMS hak file, so no real harm was done.
Couldn't agree more, Kail. EMS is, at best, an accident waiting to happen.

Aielund has become the standard for community content, as far as I am concerned. I tend to judge the quality of most all Vault DLs against that design, perhaps a bit unfairly, because Aielund was the result of an almost fanatical obsession with detail and innovation, much to our mutual benefit. It deserves to be the first one mentioned in this section IMHO.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
About EMS, though, there is a file that details spell changes, a few of which I tend to agree with. Divine Favor does Divine type damage with EMS, not magical, Deafening Clang does 5 Sonic, not 3, and lasts for 1 Turn per level. Harm and Heal are capped at 150, Blade Thirst lasts 1 Turn per level. Like in the original NWN, each player will have enough agreements and disagreements depending on their playstyle. I do think EMS is more balanced than vanilla NWN, but that's just my opinion. However, as Kail pointed out, if you're not comfortable with the alterations and / or are too lazy to learn them, like I was for a while, you can use EMSfake and play the saga with the regular magic system. This has an unfortunate side effect for Clerics and Paladins in the last battle of ACT 3. I won't get into this any further not to give any spoilers.

The TXT file with detailed info on all altered spells comes with the download in the RAR file.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content:
Maximillian Kane wrote:
About EMS, though, there is a file that details spell changes
Not really. Spell changes are not detailed properly (often it's just said it's working as per PnP rules) and the most recent updates are presented at the top of the readme file, thus forcing one to scroll down and look for less recent updates to the same feature and for the starting modification which is not always available for reference either. Short of opening up the hak and checking all the scripts there's no way to know exactly what the EMS hak does.

The one thing that the EMS is severely lacking is proper documentation. One might like its features or not, that is a personal preference but I wonder how many out there really know all that the hak is doing. I really wished the author or some revisionist would take the time to write down all the changes in place.

posts.author: RookY2K
posts.content: Ok, question regarding hakpacks and PW play: Let's say I d/l the EMS hakpack to play this module and then later want to play in a PW that does not use this hak. Does that matter at all? Do I have to uninstall any haks I have or are those haks only used in PW and modules that specifically call for them?

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
RookY2K wrote:Ok, question regarding hakpacks and PW play: Let's say I d/l the EMS hakpack to play this module and then later want to play in a PW that does not use this hak. Does that matter at all? Do I have to uninstall any haks I have or are those haks only used in PW and modules that specifically call for them?
As long as you have the room, load up any and all haks you need and leave them there. The only issues I have ever had is when a particular hak has been updated and I have an older one. In a case like that, one will typically get a diagnostic that specifies the exact file name that is missing, a clue that the hak has been revised. Some times the individual files have been provided for DL but most times you just need the latest version. But, in general, each hak that is called by a server (or module) is specific enough to avoid dichotomy problems.

Also, should you ever find a problem while playing new custom content, it is a good habit to keep some sort of dated listing of all the haks and overrides in their respective folders. That way, when you play new content and something seems amiss, you can more easily identify the "offending" hak. Not all haks and overrides are created equal!

A topic probably better posted separately, just in case others have the same question (embedded info is hard or impossible to find). Still, I hope this answers your question. Game on with complete hak autonomy!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello Everyone,

Have come here to play, hope Max doesn't mind. As the previous contributions herein have concurred, Aielund is a great adventure! At least, the first Chapter is (takes you from levels 1-9 - with companions, and soloing it, while probably possible, would be a serious waste, as well as suicidal). The end of "Nature Abhors A Vacuum" (chap1) is precisely as far as I've reached thus far. And it's the first big-boy alternate I've played since the OC/SoU/HotU, so I hope you'll forgive dumb-assery as I move through. My intention is not to do a walkthrough, merely to raise issues I encounter in Aielund that may have implications elsewhere

I'm aware that some of the issues I'll be raising are not going to be 'build-specific', but an example in Chapter 1 (and I assume throughout) is that if you're constructing a build with Bard, with an INT of 14 you'd expect 6 skill points per level (4 +INT modifier). I'm getting 8. Don't get me wrong, with my particular build this means I can max UMD and Listen and still have 15 points to play with, so no complaints! However, neither Fighter nor RDD get an additional 2, or even 1 extra point. So, I don't know which, if any, other character types attract a 'bonus', or even if any receive a minus hit on SPs. Thus, the environment in which one plays may have a direct impact on an effective build.

Blimey, that was long-winded. Hope it made some sense (and at least Empyre's noticed it as well, so it ain't just me miscalculating! And yes, Empyre, I'm using your name as a 'kitemark' without asking - sorry, but not very ).

Anyway, as it transpires, I'm now on a ship heading for Fairloch and returning a princess, which is nice. Just an observation or two, if I may...

1. If you've only played the OC etc, you have no idea of quite how dark those Neverwinter nights can be. Take a torch and use it - seriously. And I'm playing an Elf for goodness' sake!

2. 'Ride', or 'Mounted Action', or whatever the damn thing's called, might not be quite as useless as previously thought - I've just had to deal with (as in 'kill') a bloke on a horse, and actively riding it, so if that's in Chapter 1, who knows how things will progress? (Interestingly enough, when chatting with my companions I did notice that an option was to tell them, essentially, to get off their horse and drink their milk...)

3. There appear to be many new and wonderful-seeming weapons in certain merchants' stores, but I am reliably informed by Empyre that you you can't take a feat in them (eg, WF or WS) - and that Katana is differently attributed. Be careful out there!

That's it for now. Hope you don't mind me attempting to hijack this thread!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
The only question you asked is about horses. The old version of the Aielund Saga I have is from before horses were added, and the new version of the Aielund Saga that is being worked on will remove them, so I will never ride horses in the Aielund Saga.

I have read that horses break some conversations triggers. In some areas, there is a line that will trigger a conversation when you cross it, but if you are on a horse, it won't trigger, maybe because you are moving too fast. That is why horses are going to be removed, and why I am waiting for that new version before I upgrade my Aielund Saga.

If you want to be effective with any weapon you find, here's a build I made for the Aielund Saga that achieves a 44 AB with no weapon-specific feats: Universal Warrior: Fighter 18 / Bard 12 / RDD 10
However, I recommend a katana-specific build. I have used a WM build and a RDD build, and I'd gladly make non-Dev-Crit versions for you.

Cheers!

@Hip - Thinking about it, while of course you're both right and helpful in referring me to everything that's already out there, it only really encourages me to be a succubus - which, in turn, means I'll still have to feed on you good people for my builds  - see above - and I won't learn. What I will do is construct my own toon, then have a look at what's already out there as a model of perfection with which to compare and contrast. This is the long haul, brother! Otherwise, as Max hinted at nearly a year ago, there will be no future creators, only a few immortals, who we will need to worship because we know know better (I'm not bad at pompous, am I?)

(To be fair, I did exactly as I said I'm going to do hereafter (heretofore?) once before: with a Barbarian28/Bard2/RDD10 build, and discovered there were 346,000,000 better versions of it out there, so what do I know?)

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:
-clip-
@Hip - Thinking about it, while of course you're both right and helpful in referring me to everything that's already out there, it only really encourages me to be a succubus - which, in turn, means I'll still have to feed on you good people for my builds  - see above - and I won't learn. What I will do is construct my own toon, then have a look at what's already out there as a model of perfection with which to compare and contrast. This is the long haul, brother! Otherwise, as Max hinted at nearly a year ago, there will be no future creators, only a few immortals, who we will need to worship because we know know better (I'm not bad at pompous, am I?) -clip-




 
There are different ways to use a knowledge base, of course.  But I think you may be short-changing yourself with regards to dissecting the scope of pre-established builds to make your own better.

Sure, there are those who really don't have the time or inclination to design a workable build (with that view the ECB is a "Build Restaurant" where they chose from the menu)... but within the community of players I believe this to be the minority.  Most folks checking out the ECB contributions enjoy making their own decisions but are limited by their unique exposure, so do their research first.  I fall into the second category.

What's most important in the posted builds (IMHO naturally) are the discussions.  Second in significance is discovering the not-always-easy-to-discern goal of the builder.  What is it EXACTLY that he/she is trying to achieve and how does the build sequence optimize achieving that goal?  Some of the guild's feedback can be simply correcting errors or misconceptions (there was plenty of this when the game was constantly being updated).  Others draw from their own learning experience playing with an established recipe within different environments.  THOSE are the diamonds in the rough, information that is player-specific.

So, don't be afraid of sculpting your own build sequence to closely mimic someone else's contribution even on a subconscious level.  It's only natural.  What's the phrase... "Briilliant minds think alike."?  But if you feel that examining the guild's offerings beforehand will somehow jaundice your own development skills, then by all means, use the retrospective eye.  Just seems a bit counter-productive to me, though. It's akin to working on your car and then reading the manual afterwards to discover how badly you screwed up.

And yes, Max is one-of-a-kind.  For sure.

posts.content:
Hello again!

I've been playing two games in tandem - one with my little elven tank (which is on pause until the other catches him up), the other with a bastardised version of Empyre's (yes, you again!) Order of the Wyrm - Monk25/Sorcerer1/RDD14 ("Fister" version, as the more prosaic amongst us would have it). Bastardised because this isn't going to be a Dev Crit build, obviously, so I've a little license with it. One thing I have done in the first few levels is taken some Heal skill points (making sure I've still got my 8 Lore points for RDD), 'cos it's really tough going without any ability to use health scrolls, particularly if your Cleric gets splatted. If you like, I'll post my final build when I get to the end (I'm doing some minor remodelling on the hoof, as it were).

Anyway, I digress. I'm in Fairloch in the 2nd mod, and thought it was interesting that there's a quest on offer to my LG Wyrm-boy that wasn't to my CG Elf-tank. It may be that it's predicated on my getting the Pally companion that I couldn't get last time (wasn't lawful enough), so I'm unclear as to cause and effect, but the Cathedral became a lot more interesting. Oh, and I didn't bother with Clarity potions last time, but they're a damn fine idea if you get the quest! Don't know yet whether I'll be barred from any other quest my other character could take.

Have since dropped the Pally in a pub, and picked up a Barbar instead (in another pub). Risky move - of the 3 of us, no one's a healer. But I'm rich as Croesus, so can afford loads of potions/kits. We'll see how it goes...

Also potentially of interest, I notice that I'm almost a full level better off with this build currently (levelled up to 10 while still on the ship) - same companions, same quests (during the 1st mod anyway), so who knows? Still having a grand old time of it!

Oh, and Empyre, will be taking both your DEX-ing Monk/SD/Fighter and at least one of the Universal Warriors around Aielund next time - hope that's ok.

Cheers

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I am thrilled that you like my builds, but I recommend that you play another campaign in between, like SoU + the Nether Scrolls (bridge module) + HotU + the Sands of Fate series, which brings you all the way to level 40.

I'd thought HotU was a direct follow-on from SoU, but I'm happy to bow to wisdom. I also seem to recall something about acid being handy for Sands of Fate, so I'll see what I can do.

I do intend to complete at least one complete run-through of Aielund first, however.

Cheers!

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
There's two versions.  I have played neither.  Perhaps Empyre can offer a recommendation.
The Nether Scrolls v1.15
The Nether Scrolls (HotU Version)

As for concerning yourself about the starting level for HotU... don't bother.  The CRs will eventually catch up to your toon and status quo will be regained.  That is if you don't mind getting such skimpy XP rewards until the chapter ends.  By Ch 2, your toon should be relatively close to where a Level 15 toon starting HotU would have been.  Besides, from what I've read, the bridge is short, your toon won't level that much (1-3 levels, at most IIRC) and you will gain some added storyline to where SoU left off.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Marvellous - thanks, guys.

Actually, it will be interesting to go back to SoU. I've always struggled with it since I blasted through it a couple of times early on, when I mistakenly believed it to be the follow-on to the OC (47 XP for deading a dragon seemed a tad mean, which should have been a clue!). I now know better. However, I guess the problem I've had is that I know what I should be doing, but am not yet sufficiently matured as a character to do it (by which I mean as an in-game character, so no cheap gags, please!). But one of the nice things is that, at least until you reach Undrentide, the gear isn't overly spectacular, so you actually get to know your character and what different feats and skills can do, rather than relying on the shiny things.

No play today - boo. Will try and squeeze some in tomorrow.

Cheers!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Meanwhile, back in Aielund...

I'm now in Return of the Ironlord with my (Empyre's) Monk/RDD/Sorcerer (currently L19), and have a few questions/observations - without dropping thunking great spoilers, I hope.

Manged to roll through Part 2 with Barbarian and Rogue companions - was tempted by a cute little Druid, but thought I'd try full tanking - just needed a few more rest breaks, but it went okay without all the added Druid buffs. And the AI worked fine with the Rogue making his own mind up whether to use melee or ranged weaponry, which was nice! Don't really have much to say about Part 2 other than it was great fun - mixing outdoor expanses with indoor crawling really well. Only a little thing...I'm guessing the author (architect?) had a linear plot in mind that I didn't follow, resulting in my having some very odd conversations and picking up several quests before they were assigned (in one instance completing it), but nothing problematic, and it's better not to be forced down one particular path by the DM imo.

However, as I started in Part 3 it quickly became apparent that I should have been rather more of a pack-rat, and hung onto some of the prestigious items. Highly irritating to have to fork out a fortune for equipment that's worse than you had previously! Also irksome given that, for once, I'd been a good boy and done some 'proper' inventory management

Also, the AI seems to have taken a downturn. If a person has a WS in BS and I equip them with one (+3), I don't then expect them to swap it out for a +2 Battleaxe they happen to be carrying as soon as any melee begins! I also gave everyone lots of heal kits and potions and they steadfastly refused to use them, leading to far too many deaths (theirs) and reloads (ran out of Raise Dead scrolls). However, I'm now back in Culdeny (which seems to be considerably reinforced) and can pick up an old friend who could help with this...

And now for the question, also about companions. Up until now, they've all been single class, but I now have a Rogue/Wiz - and I'd like them to progess in one class only (Wiz, 'cos their spells are somewhat sucky at the moment, while their de-trapping and unlocking are fine) from now on. In SoU/HotU, if I remember correctly, you could tell any companion to do this (Deekin rocks!), but I don't seem to be getting that option here. Am I missing the dialogue option on how to do it, or does it not exist?

I'm aware this is a lot of prattling for one little question, but I've been away. Sorry.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Savage definitely had a story in mind, but it's a good story. Being a pack rat has served me well in the past. If a henchman keeps switching to a weapon you don't want him to use, take it away from him and have him carry something else for you instead. You don't have a choice what class she levels as, but IIRC, Criosa levels up as Wizard from that point on anyway.

posts.author: Stagmeister

It was, therefore, no question about replacing him with the lovely Nellise, who has been extraordinarily good (so far).

Er, having just levelled to 20 (conclusion of the re-entering of the Exiled Knight's tomb - one of the few doors still open!), Criosa has just gone to Rogue 11, Wizard 9. Arse. Maybe it's because I've got Nell with me? Oh, and IIRC - whassat?

Cheers!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Yes, Savage made the Aieklund Saga, and has since written a series of books telling the tale. Here is his Aielund Saga site.

IIRC = If I Recall (or Remember) Correctly, and if Criosa leveled as Rogue, then apparently I didn't remember correctly. I remember for sure that she doesn't switch back and forth between the two classes. I have never felt handicapped by having her around.

When you are expecting a battle, as Criosa and Nelise to cast a series of buffing spells. Ask Nelise first, because she has more spells so she takes longer. Criosa will be finished first despite starting second.

"Thank you for downloading this module, I hope it brings you much enjoyment!
The pacing for this adventure should provide everyone a lot of fun, as

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:
 I'm sorry if this makes me come across as really stupid (no comments, please), but I've tried everything else I can think of to beat the tin minotaur, and Nell, Criosa and I always seem to end up deader than several very dead things.
 
It is usually customary when seeking solutions to a specific situation to furnish full disclosure. Kinda like solving a tech problem.  e.g....

What is the class combo level you have reached at this juncture?  HP, AB & AC wouldn't hurt either unless you are a caster of some sort, but I suspect that is not the case.  In any event, use the stats with your full gear equipped and describe any enhancements you feel are important like DR penetration, immunities, haste, etc.

Generally, what is your toon's skill set?

Are you able to cast summons via scrolls or items and, if so, have you used them in conjunction with your companion?

What buffs do you have access to and can you dispel or breach magic?

What sort of special attributes does your "uber" foe possess?  And related... if it can buff/cast spells, does your toon have enough Spellcraft to ID them via the combat log?  Is it a True Seer? If not, invis pots should buy you heal/re-buff time.

Naturally, if you are having trouble determining the full characterization of a foe, it would take someone with module experience like Empyre to help enlighten you.  That's always the first step in defeating a foe... figure out the strengths and weaknesses and then plan a strategy around those.  Strategy-wise, it could be as simple as pulling the boss away from its "comfort zone" to where your party is waiting.  Can your toon set traps (assuming that they are even available, of course)?

Basically, I am suggesting that rather than spoiling the pleasure of personal conquest, you may have it in your power to achieve your goal by just looking at the problem from a totally different perspective.  At least that how I solve the seemingly-unsolvable.

BTW, this a module-specific topic so anyone reading it should automatically expect the possibility of spoilers popping up, though it wouldn't hurt to use the handy spoiler code if you are really concerned that much.

Ah...that explains my consistent failures, then (though he does take some smidgen of divine damage, which only served to egg me on). Thanks, Empyre. Guess I'm just leaving the townsfolk to their grisly fate.
 
Empyre addressed the combat point about possible "special attributes" of the foe... which changes everything.  Plot always does.

Seems a bit cruel that the mod designer would allow a plot creature to go hostile.  Sort of reminds me of those Gulnan plot zombies in the Warrens where I interrupted the convo by attacking.  It screws up the script and they go hostile.  Took me forever to lock the invulnerable thing into a room to stop chasing me! 
Oh, and a technical aargh - how do I fill the quote box?
Use the Quote option of the post instead of the Reply.  You can remove any superfluous text in the quote by clicking inside the quote, highlighting and deleting.  But a caution:  Always type a bit of your reply after the quoted section before editting the quote text.  If you accidentally remove any control characters (usually when deleting near the end of the quote), it can "freeze" you out from adding reply text and force a redo.

Another slightly more tedious method (occasionally handy when trying to quote more than one post in single reply) is to type:
{quote="Poster's ID goes here"}
some text
{/quote}
... (using brackets instead of curlies), then copy/paste the part of any post you wish to quote where I typed "some text" between the code.  Rinse and repeat for as many separate posts as you like.  Poster's ID goes here is the guild name of the quoted text owner and make sure to enclose in double quotes if you want the name to show up in the upper LH corner of the quote.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
HipRedux wrote:
Seems a bit cruel that the mod designer would allow a plot creature to go hostile.  Sort of reminds me of those Gulnan plot zombies in the Warrens where I interrupted the convo by attacking.  It screws up the script and they go hostile.

 
I'm trying the quote thingy - I'd assumed that was what you clicked if you wanted to leave a "Take it JZ" (hang on, that's not right) sort of postscript. Hope it works...

If it does, then this will make a lot more sense! One of the things I really like about Aeilund is the lack of cut-scenes, even plot critical events have been scripted in (eg, the end of Act II, Defender of the Crown, when the bad dudes troop in while your toon's having a chat with the Duke). I guess that in this instance, however, it would be like having big Meph available for potential (albeit pointless) clobbering after thumping the Valsharess into the middle of next week.

Right, let's see how the quotey-dumplings have done...

EDIT: Yee-and-indeed-Hah!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hurrah! Have finally made it into Act 4! The battle for Highmarch was stupendous, and tough as hell. I don't think spoilers signs are needed here, but it's probably worth mentioning that buying, selling and upgrading gear isn't really a good idea at the start of the Act (mind you, it won't hurt either way). Nell, Criosa and I have just finished snake-wrangling in the desert and are looking for something to drink...

Oh, one minor question - the wee dragon, Spartan - from early in Act 3 - is he worth grabbing at some point, or is he a mere embellishment?

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Travelling around with a dragon in your party probably adds some coolness to your image as a seasoned adventurer. But for me - and my characters,I might add - it ends there.
And he doesn't really fit well into any party I might conjure up.

Edit: Finished the last sentence. Blame it on mobile phone editi

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: The coolness factor is all Spartan has going for him. He is not very useful to the party. I hired him once, and wound up loading the saved game before hiring him and then not hiring him. I always go with Criosa and Robert in chapter 3 because there will be plenty of the Nelise and Criosa combination later.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:
I always go with Criosa and Robert in chapter 3 because there will be plenty of the Nelise and Criosa combination later.
 
Initially I went for Nelise and Criosa because all Robert seemed to do was be afraid and/or die, so I left him in the church in Culdeny (mean of me, I know, given his hatred of clerics). I've since had a rethink, and realised it was probably me mismanaging both him and his inventory, so I'll give him a proper go next time. I also hadn't realised that I'd inherit Nel and Criosa (who, interesingly, has changed from Rogue 15/Wizard 9 at the end of Act 3 to Rogue 12/Wizard 12 in Act 4) in the next part.

As a by the way, I'm currently testing my Fighter 14/ CoT 18/Rogue 8 dual-wield build in this trip through Aielund, and I think I've cocked up what he's wielding. Again. When I took him through SoU and HotU I had him with Scimitar and Short Sword (which would probably have been ideal in the OC), and wished I'd gone for something else there - and now in Aielund I've opted for Katana and Mace, when Bastard or Long Sword and Small Hammer would probably have been wiser. Oh well. Maybe it's a case of the grass is always greener...

Oh, and thanks, both for the gen on Spartan - cool but useless (and probably impossible to squeeze into a dungeon crawl)

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Just curious why you wouldn't take the Dex bump at Lvl 4 to enable earlier DWing, Empyre?  There's no rush compiling STR with all the impending RDD levels and no DevCrit goal.  Perhaps those sweet swords you cited were only available much later?  Or rather... being concerned about hitting with the DW penalty during pre-epic?  You have early bard levels and enough dump opportunities to be using DR/concealment scroll buffs so AC should not be all that big a deal without the shield.  Dex 15 + a 4 roll of Cat pot yields +3 Dex AC, +3 reflex and +3 Tumble early on so the odd number can turn out more in your favor than maybe anticipated.

Overall, it looks very solid and easy to play with an efficient skill set and nice saves vs. spells.  Give it a name like Aielund Draco Swordsmith or something more inventive. 

P.S. What would be extremely helpful for aspiring Aielund adventurers (and if you can find the time) would be to insert horizontal lines after each level that you, from experience, usually reach at end of each of the modules in the series.  I suppose that could be construed as spoilerific, but BioWare did it for all their campaigns so it must be an acceptable practice.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I was indeed concerned about taking the dual-wield AB penalty before my AB got good. I plan to wear heavy armor, so I would get only +1 AC from DEX. Nevertheless, I agree with you and took your advice, moving the DEX dump from level 12 to level 8, getting the dual-wield feats several levels earlier.
I also took your suggestion to change the name. The new name reflects that the build is for Aielund, has RDD in it, and dual-wields. I researched the save games from all 8 of my previous play-throughs of Aielund to see when chapters end.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Have just completed the Battle for Bracksworth - WTF! Very sad now. I guess for plot reasons there's no way for the Persuade check to work in the scenario just prior to the battle, but ouch. Cups were raised, tears were shed, hearts were sore, but vengeance now runs cold in our veins. Excellent storytelling from Savant. Think we're off to Trinity again now, maybe via the Baba encampment.

And that's a lovely build (above) Empyre - will you be posting it in the Full Epic forum?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I wish you well with your Persuasive Archer, and would be intrigued to find out what happens - particularly when and if Nell gets involved - you may well win your checks, but, bless her, she's the one who'll most likely to scuttle any potential entente cordiale. After all, she's the one who prevents any potential armistice with the Ironlord in the previous chapter. God love her, but she can be a gobby sod who makes no friends when she's that way out (hand raises to cover eyes, head shakes. "Oh Nell, please, not again. Just button it for once."). Ah, but then you don't use her in Act 3, do you? One-Eyed-Bob probably has a considerably more pragmatic approach...

Enjoy the OC and Hairybreast's Redemption!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
You should use Robert in CH 3 once. He is very handy in a fight, and funny in conversations. You might also try a female PC at the same time ;).
Good ol' Nelise. A lot of the time, she is saying what I am thinking, but without tact. I give her a try in Ch 3 some time, but not with the archer. I have also never used Maggie in Ch 2.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
My intention is to play a female PC with the adaptation of Mick's Halfling Champion and take Cap'n Bob with me in my next run through - see what he can really do.

I have taken Maggie in Chapter 2 before (and have just met her again in Chapter 4 of my current game), and a grand addition she makes - particularly in her own druidy mission, though I'll admit Valennia cuts a more imposing figure. I don't think I'll be taking another Hin with me while I'm playing one - it'd just look too comic, the two of us bursting out from between Ronan's legs and into the fray

Oh, Empyre, you might be interested given your involvement - I've just seen a TV ad for Doom.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Have you tried that paladin (Sir William?) yet in Ch 2? He is in the inn closest to the castle. He won't want to associate with you if you are too far from lawful good. His rejection of me when I was chaotic good is what led me to use Valennia the for first time, a few play-throughs ago. I found Sir William's quest easily, but I never found Valennia's quest. Did you?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
No. As far as I've been able to discern, she merely gives some history to Morik's overthrow by Erag and the legend of Reikthor - sort of a foreshadow of the Baba doings in Chapter 3. To be fair, Maggie's quest is one you pick up anyway (Feybourne), you just get it from her, rather than the mayor of Amalis. I'll confess that the only reason I've had Maggie in the party is when I'm testing out a build that's melee orientated - lest Val's awesome thumping skew my combat capabilities. Maybe it's the case that 3 of the 4 potential companions in Ch 2 don't have specific, character-only quests - much as Nell and Dante don't in Ch 1. It'll be interesting to see if Robert has more to add to his recuperation in the Valley of Silence story in Ch 3.

As far as Sir William is concerned, I've picked him up purely for his quest (which, it appears, you can only get if he's in your party or you're a pally yourself), then dumped him back where I found him (nicking his gear first, naturally, but leaving him in some lord's attire - after all, a nude paladin loitering in a bar would look a tad odd.). He was just too pompous for my taste, and would annoy me to death. I had the same rejection issue with him as a CG character, but have had no problem as NG - which has become my default alignment in Aielund.

I've also just realised that the character I've recently posted in the Full Epic forum is the first time I've ever (in 18 months) used a longsword build - there just seemed to be too many good ones to ignore.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hmm. Last time, as it was my first at these heady levels, I simply took it for granted that when I inherited Terinus, he was a perpetual L30 Wiz (still no bad thing), so it struck me as odd that he continued to level up to 34 this time (but not to 35). Equally, I thought, "well Nellise has just got lots of cool new stuff and enhancements, so I can understand why she won't level up any further." Then, that was at L33, so this time I thought I'd get to 34 before capping her off - hence my earlier trip to the Ethereal Plane (I've done Twilight first both times). It was Robert that concerned me most. Nary a problem last time, but this time at levels 32, 33 and 34 I had a dialogue option to ask him to level up, which was odd in itself, followed by a yellow script line in the bottom dialogue box that read "not scripted for level 32, (etc)". Then suddenly, I level to 35 and so does he!

In a way, it's of minor concern, given where we're all at, but if it's symptomatic of something else I don't know whether to go for a reload or not - particularly given the teething troubles I had in loading it in the first place. Aargh!

Oh well, I'll finish Monk-Boy's run-through - which, btw, has been serene compared with my previous completion (further cementing Order of the Wyrm as one of my all-time favourite builds. posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: In the build, I have Armor Skin as the Monk bonus feat at level 39 and Epic Prowess as the RDD bonus feat at level 40, but in Aielund, we never reach those levels. If you want to replace a couple Great Strength feats with AS and EP, to get them before the end of Aielund, that would be fine. If you find yourself getting hit a lot, take AS first, and if you find yourself missing a lot, take EP first.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Just because I haven't begun playing Aielund yet doesn't mean it isn't on the top of my "to-do" list and also doesn't mean I am not following all the nuances in this thread with bated breath.  I look at Stagmeister as the sacrificial lamb (oh, lambs are so cuddly and furry, right? )

But I am betting the level-up package for Robert just didn't set the variable right for you when it should have, Stagmeister. That is one benefit of frequent saves in SP play... reload when things seem amiss even though it may seem tedious to retrack.  YOU have the control whereas on PWs, only the DM/admin has the "power" to adjust anomalies. So SAVE! Dammit! SAVE!

I always place priority on Epic Prowess over the key ability bumps since EP = 2 Grt STR.  In other words, EP gains in one level what Grt STR gains in 3.  Sure, a bit more dmg but meh... hitting is where it's at (unless you are racing to qualify for DevCrit). But like Empyre pointed out, Armor Skin can rise above the to-hit significance when it's your toon getting hit too often to make much progress. Haven't checked the build you are using, but Expertise could mediate the problem as well (assuming your AB is adequate, naturally, and you have the feat). 

I like to read about on-the-fly content-specific build adjustments like these because they are a product of real-time experience and cannot be gleaned from a sample build. Timing is everything!

Carry on, Aielund addicts!

I've just embarked on a run-through with a Barbarian/CoT/Rogue build, and I thought I'd share something, by way of a warning, that happened in Culdeny which I haven't encountered before. I decided to have my toon display a slightly more "robust" line of questioning in my discussion with Robert Bartlett (he started it - accusing me of breaking his door down when I had the key from the Mayor). This led to both Roberts Black and Bartlett running off in a huff without giving me any info, which in turn led Ariel Smith (the guard commander) to be somewhat vexed about my approach, and now I've returned from helping the Rangers out with the poachers none of the stores will trade with me (except for the Dwarf in the pub). This is something of a nuisance!

I could probably just about live with the inconvenience, but I suspect a reload is in order, because the Bracksworth shops and Ranger Quartermaster will run out of coin quickly (the Dwarf already has), and then I'll be stumped. Annoyingly, I'll have to take it from my first arrival in the town - for some reason I didn't do a name save after either the Dockmaster or church quests. A salutory lesson. Play nice until it's time not to. And remember to save. I are a nidiot.

Cheers

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:
I decided to have my toon display a slightly more "robust" line of questioning in my discussion with Robert Bartlett (he started it - accusing me of breaking his door down when I had the key from the Mayor). This led to both Roberts Black and Bartlett running off in a huff without giving me any info, which in turn led Ariel Smith (the guard commander) to be somewhat vexed about my approach, and now I've returned from helping the Rangers out with the poachers none of the stores will trade with me (except for the Dwarf in the pub). This is something of a nuisance!
 
Well, since this is SP, you could try resetting factions in order to avoid a redo.  I've run into an issue like this when I accidentally killed a neutral animal like a rat and then all the merchants went hostile (all members of the same faction).   Of course, you could also track down the variable that is causing this and reset that but can become tedious finding it and actually defeats the RP aspects that Balkoth undoubtedly built into the module.

TBH, I like situations like this because they reflect so closely PnP events and very tricky to design.  Normally, in PnP, we would have our best negotiator do all the haggling until the offender was able to become reinstated into society again.  But alas, in SP, there is no such alternative since you have neither a sympathetic party member to take up the gauntlet nor a DM to aid in dealing with the consequences of your toon's actions.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I believe I've figured out the issue I'd been having on my first visit to Culdeny (see above if you want details). After a couple of reloads when the same thing happened, I tried two more, both of which worked. It was all a question of intimidation. My current toon's a Barbarian for her first 8 levels, and Culdeny is reached at level 3, and if you don't level up (taking Intimidate, natch) until after you've spoken with Ronald Bartlett (apologies, I called him Robert last time), you're ok. Equally, if you do some more stuff (ie, helping the Rangers) and then talk with him at level 5, you're scary enough for rough questioning to work. It's just level 4 where the problem arises - too scary for him to patronise you, but not scary enough to cow him.

Thus...hurrah!

Oh, and the other build I'm taking through (depends on my mood at the time) has some Bard in him, and I've discovered a very mini Bard questette in Fairloch that has never been available to me before. I'm sure the great and good have found it previously, but if anyone else would like to know, please ask.

Cheers

I'd been in before, and a rehearsal is taking place, but never had any joy in conversation (except for "Go away, I'm busy."). This time, I was allowed to listen (in the same way you do when on the roof of the Host Tower in the OC - so be patient), before interacting.

There are probably several solutions, but the build I'm using is a variation of the Elven Dragon Dual-Wielder you first provided me with 20 months ago and only has 3 Bard levels at this point (overall level 10 or 11), so I'm probably restricted in my options and their outcomes. What I do know is that the Bartlett family are probably never going to put me on their Christmas card list. I got some decent-ish loot (might be useful for your Persuasive Archer, but I can't remember if you've got Bard in that mix) and had no adverse reactions subsequently, so am hoping all is well.

Hope this helps.

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Have just finished the saga for the 3rd time. I used a variation of Mick Dagger's Epic Brawler Champion (Fighter 18 / CoT 18 / Monk 4) - a brilliant melee build that may be found as build 196 in Hip's Fantastic Contrapulator.

For the first time, I hit level 37. This both pleased and annoyed me.

Pleased: because it's one more level than I expected - despite my forgetting to have a chat with Salinder in chapter 2 (which I think must give xp), and having no major character-specific side quests (I got Zach's Monk quest in chapter 3, but it's only a baby one). All of which means 37 is eminently do-able, with a full set of companions throughout (in this instance cleric and ranger in chapter 1, rogue and barbarian in chapter 2, rogue and cleric in chapter 3 - sorry Empyre, Bob was superfluous, and I won't tell you about chapter 4 in case you haven't played it.)

Annoyed: because I'd spent way too long tinkering with Mick's build in its 30s - to the extent that I'd taken Monk 4 as a skills dump at level 32 (meaning, effectively, I'd lose +1AC from Tumble, rather than 2). Thus, at level 36, I thought I'd maxed what I could, sitting on Fighter 16 / CoT 16 (maxing my saves) and Monk 4, with both Armour Skin (taken at L34) and Epic Prowess (taken much earlier, at L24). Then..."oh, what to do now?". I was lucky, though - I could take level 37 as Monk and still get another 5 points in Tumble (another +1 to AC), which knocked the spots off everything else available - ie, nothing (I'm discounting an additional 2 HPs at this stage).

I suppose what I'm saying, albeit going around the houses, is that it's worth building for level 37 in Aielund, rather than just 36. Admittedly, it only came within 2 minutes of the final battle, but - thinking of companions as much as anything (buffs, spells and the like) - you can still rest before going epic on the bad dude's ass, and a wee bit extra could make all the difference.

Actually, while I'm here, I'm not entirely sure about chapter 4. There's a natural cohesion to the first 3 chapters, and indeed in the earlier elements of chapter 4. But after assorted regicides (actual and attempted), it starts getting a bit...silly. There are areas that could well produce good mods in themselves, and others you can't even enter. Now, this may be some extended foreshadowing, but is the final chapter of such an epic saga really the place to do that?

Don't get me wrong, it's still a country mile better than any other SP game I've played, it's just that the last bit rankles a touch.

But, to be honest, i didn't get your point. What did you find silly?
"There are areas that could well produce good mods in themselves, and others you can't even enter. Now, this may be some extended foreshadowing, but is the final chapter of such an epic saga really the place to do that?"
And can you be more specific?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi Vecho, happy to talk about the game (haven't read the books yet, they're on my 'to do' list) - after all, that's why I hijacked this thread from Max in the first place!

Before I start, I will say again that it is a brilliant saga, so any criticisms are only in comparison with what I see as the best bits. And I'll try not to give away spoilers, for those yet to experience the saga.

I think Part 4 (The Fall of Aielund) starts excellently (others will disagree, I'm sure). Sure, having all your hard-won cool gear taken away is a well-worn staple, but it is handled so much better here: there is plot purpose to it, and you don't just find all your old stuff lying around in a chest somewhere. It also forces you to think as a player. I don't know about you, but I was feeling a bit cocky in my abilities by the end of Part 3, and this was the slap in the face I needed to wake up again. The narrative remains 'realistic' and drives you forward, with moments of great pathos and humour thrown in. Then comes the twist with Osric, which was also handled very well.

My moans (if they can be called that) concern events after being beamed into Terry's tower. I chose the word "silly" poorly, sorry, more like unsatisfying. Go througha series of doors to get bigger and scarier weapons? That doesn't seem to me as clever a plot device as Savant has demonstrated he's capable of. And he won't even let you go through a couple of those doors, so why have them there at all?

As to what's behind the doors...Twilight has plenty of scope for a full storyline: we're given interesting characters and hints of back-story that could have been (and maybe are in the books) a prelude to a lengthy adventure in its own right. And then it's over. Hmm. The short trip to the Ethereal Plane is pretty inconsequential. I do like the tying together of things in Assumption, handled very nicely, even though the scraps with both Insidiae and Abadon left me feeling a little underwhelmed.

Then there's the mind flayers - sorry saqarin (ye gods, how I detest them! I swear, ever since Baldur's Gate 2, whenever I encounter them a little part of my soul dies). Unlike every other baddies in the saga, their motivation for what they're about to do is piss poor. Surely creatures of their supreme intelligence wouldn't simply employ "Hulk bash, Hulk smash" tactics?

There you go, those are my quibbles. Nothing major, but the whole conclusion arc just left me a little...flat. Hope that explains a bit better for you. I'm not expecting you to agree, of course!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Having doors that you can't go through is a long-standing technique to make places seem bigger than they really are. I've used that trick in my Doom maps.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Cheers Empyre - I understand that bit, now - and to be fair to Savant, there's a little interjection from Terry before approaching one unopenable, and a "something dreadful this way comes" from the other, so he didn't just leave them hanging there.

As I said, minor issues

posts.author: Vecho
posts.content:
="My moans (if they can be called that) concern events after being beamed into Terry's tower. I chose the word "silly" poorly, sorry, more like unsatisfying. Go througha series of doors to get bigger and scarier weapons? That doesn't seem to me as clever a plot device as Savant has demonstrated he's capable of. And he won't even let you go through a couple of those doors, so why have them there at all?"

Personally i don't have problem with a few doors being unavailable to me. It would be unrealistic to open the whole multiple universe to the players in just one mod.
From what i gathered, Terry was trying to get the weapon which were powerful enough to go through the defence of Mind Flayers, which was reasonable. If you are going to rebel against your tyrant, who are more advanced than you, the first things you need are adequate and enough weapons as highly technological as possible. With all the weapons left by your master stolen, you have to find some in other foreign area outside the control of your master. So, I think the plot of looking for weapons is fine. As for the limited access of other planes, I can think of several reasons, like that Terry's knowledge of the multiple universes was not without boundary and these few planes open to the players were what he gathered for all those years under the service of the Mind Flayers.

TBH, i have some issues with the way the Mind Flayers manipulating the world of Aielund. Why bother manipulating when you had the power to eliminate all life form in this world. After all, what the Mind Flayers need was just the mineral alone.

="As to what's behind the doors...Twilight has plenty of scope for a full storyline: we're given interesting characters and hints of back-story that could have been (and maybe are in the books) a prelude to a lengthy adventure in its own right. And then it's over. Hmm. The short trip to the Ethereal Plane is pretty inconsequential. I do like the tying together of things in Assumption, handled very nicely, even though the scraps with both Insidiae and Abadon left me feeling a little underwhelmed."

The story in Twilight from the books is a little different from the game, but is just as short as the game. But i think Twillight serves it's purpose and to expend it is quite beyond the scope of the mod.


="Then there's the mind flayers - sorry saqarin (ye gods, how I detest them! I swear, ever since Baldur's Gate 2, whenever I encounter them a little part of my soul dies). Unlike every other baddies in the saga, their motivation for what they're about to do is piss poor. Surely creatures of their supreme intelligence wouldn't simply employ "Hulk bash, Hulk smash" tactics?"

I do think that the rebel went too smooth which made the Mind Flayers looking rather silly and not smart enough.


Overall, i think the author were doing a very good job of trying to bring the story in Aielund into a bigger context, that is, the multiple universes.
The books gave me a very good time, but the new series, with a 10-14 years old girl as a main character, is a little disappointing. I really don't like reading a adventure of a kid.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Vecho wrote:
From what i gathered, Terry was trying to get the weapon which were powerful enough to go through the defence of Mind Flayers, which was reasonable. If you are going to rebel against your tyrant, who are more advanced than you, the first things you need are adequate and enough weapons as highly technological as possible. With all the weapons left by your master stolen, you have to find some in other foreign area outside the control of your master. So, I think the plot of looking for weapons is fine.

Overall, i think the author were doing a very good job of trying to bring the story in Aielund into a bigger context, that is, the multiple universes.

 
Please don't get me wrong, I think how the end-game was implemented was fine, my issue was more about the why. It's like the author said, "I can't think past this point - wait! I know, let's have them beamed up to a spaceship, and on the way they can start playing in bits of the multiverse!". It's the seeming lack of imagination (for want of a better word) that leaves me a bit, "meh". It's a sandwich, where everything else has been a feast. But that's only because Savant has spoiled me with the depth, complexity and completeness of his plot to that point.

Oh, and the real bugger of the weapon hunt is that (unless you're a katana, falchion, whip or trident wielder) you'll either have the best weapons already or will find better ones (bucketfuls of +8 longswords with electric damage, anyone?) on the mind flayer ship itself, which Terry must have known. And, of course, there's the possibility of abusing Terry's own enhance weapon capability. Which further makes me wonder, "why do it this way?" There's some reasonable defensive gear, I suppose, and it is amusing watching Robert running around apparently naked (actually wearing Hell Armour) with a big black hat on and cloak billowing in his wake, but I suspect that's not the picture Savant wants me to remember the final conflict by...

Again, I'm only picking at scabs. It's a marvellous series, and I'd commend it to all.

posts.author: Vecho
posts.content:
="Oh, and the real bugger of the weapon hunt is that (unless you're a katana, falchion, whip or trident wielder) you'll either have the best weapons already or will find better ones (bucketfuls of +8 longswords with electric damage, anyone?) on the mind flayer ship itself, which Terry must have known. And, of course, there's the possibility of abusing Terry's own enhance weapon capability. "

Yeah, that one is implemented badly, although i can understand the reasons behind it.
If the author make some very unique and powerful weapons, he or she will always runs the risk that the players do not master that kind of weapons, which is also a risk for players when deciding which kind of weapons to specify. So, here come the enhancing ability of Terry as a solution.
For me, i always have a hard time when deciding which 1-h weapons to focus on while playing SP module. Scimitar is more powerful than a long sword. But long sword is more common and easy to get your hands on an enchanted one when exploring, which is my impression from several years of playing SP module.

In Swordflight, the player can find some very good gems, which comes with a bit of lore, during the quest that will update their own weapons, which i think is a better way of giving players the weapons they need than simply letting Terry have the enhancing ability.

Yeah. It is really frustrating when finding out the weapons in that spaceship are just as good as the ones that you have gone through so much trouble to get to.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Vecho wrote:
For me, i always have a hard time when deciding which 1-h weapons to focus on while playing SP module. Scimitar is more powerful than a long sword. But long sword is more common and easy to get your hands on an enchanted one when exploring, which is my impression from several years of playing SP module.

In Swordflight, the player can find some very good gems, which comes with a bit of lore, during the quest that will update their own weapons, which i think is a better way of giving players the weapons they need than simply letting Terry have the enhancing ability.

 
I agree with you totally. And it tends to push you towards choosing weapons you're pretty sure you'll come across throughout the game - it's all very well investing the various foci and specializations in something like Dwarven Waraxe, only to find there's only one in the entire game - very frustrating. I suppose once you've played the modules more than once you get more of a feel for what will be available (although random treasure can ruin that), but we can't have everything. And, if you find yourself with a "spare" feat, weapon proficiency in exotic at least means you'll be able to wield anything that comes your way (barring racial/class specific ones, of course).

The Swordflight solution seems like a good way of dealing with this - I look forward to playing deeper into the game to see what happens.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:
...it's all very well investing the various foci and specializations in something like Dwarven Waraxe, only to find there's only one in the entire game - very frustrating. I suppose once you've played the modules more than once you get more of a feel for what will be available (although random treasure can ruin that), but we can't have everything.



 
That's why I always play a non-focused cleric multiclass (usually with a UMD class mixed in)  the first time through any unfamiliar content.  With GMW, Darkfire and umpteen divine buffs, they can turn any mundane weapon into an enviable work of art and even bypass every DR.  All that's needed are the proficiencies and you are ready to rumble with whatever happens to fall into your lap by random fate.   Of course, that rules out classes like CoT and WM but, meh, at least you'll discover the item bias and if the CC is that good, take advantage the next time through.

If it turns out that the environment is too high magic for a cleric to dominate, I'll just pass on furthering the adventure because that sort of item prop-focused design has never been to my liking anyway, good story or not.   Either that or restart with an AA (another class that is also item prop-independent) as soon as I notice the trend of the magic level.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Ooh, there's always one who ruins a good whine by talking sense, isn't there?  I was just being the knuckle-running heavy infantry in the corner of the bar bemoaning these new-fangled, fancy-dan ways of waging war.

Seriously, that's sound advice, Hip - thanks. Equally, Empyre's Universal Warrior 2 (build 43 in your search engine) takes a different, yet similarly pragmatic approach.

Oh, and for those who are not inclined to high-magic environments, don't let this discussion put you off Aielund. Certainly until well into the final part you won't find items above +5 enhancement, and you won't just find those ones lying around all over the place. It's just during the end-game that things escalate. Iirc, in part 1 (level 1-9) you're confined to +1s max, with a very occasional +2; part 2 (level 9-18) delivers more +2s and a few +3s; part 3 (level 18-24) sees more +3s and the odd +4 (if you get a +5, you'll have earned it); and up to about level 30 in part 4, +5 is the max.

Cheers

Nor am I a fraidy cat - wearing a hat that gives fear immunity.

I'm currently at DwD 10 / Fighter 7 / CoT 4 (overall level 21). My AB is 35/30/25/20 (with STR 20 +3 Belt +2 Gloves, WF and EWF in Battleaxe, wielding a +4 Battleaxe, Def Stance on). I don't get it - is it me, or maybe a wee glitch?

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
I'm sure Empyre will be by soon for suggestions but for my own edification...

Are you saying that a convo with Scar should be occuring and is getting skipped as soon as your toon comes within perception range or that you just aren't doing any damage for a scripted combat scenario?  Maybe he just hates dwarves (or likes the way they crunch when chewed)

The first thing that comes to mind is DR.  Does the combat log show that a DR spell effect is being whittled down gradually?  Most of the DR buffs are +5 which will defeat your +4 weapon until you've broken it down unless you can crit reliably.  Otherwise, if the creature has a DR skin with +5 or greater, methinks you are screwed... unless you find a +5 weapon (or whatever enchantment will beat the creature DR).  It doesn't matter so much if the weapon is your toon's WF or not.  It's the enchantment that matters most as long as you can hit occasionally.  Let's hopes he doesn't self-heal much because small damage can become extremely tedious and frustrating.

I remember getting flummoxed by Belial in one of the OC modules because the highest melee enchantment offered was +3 (he had a +5 DR with serious soak) so he seemed godly.  There were, however, some xbows with +5 on them (oft times ranged weapons are given higher enchantments than the melee weapons for some reason).  I was able to dispatch him ~eventually~ by pecking away, healing and side-stepping his most dangerous attacks with many stacks of mundane bolts.  It's probably not an option for this particular encounter you are describing because Belial was more-or-less a captive behind an energy field and could not chase my toon down while I shot from distance.  But perhaps there are other higher-enchanted weapons that you could equip for this one situation?

Part 3, eh?  Taking notes.

I'll try an earlier reload (which will be annoying, as I actually persuaded the Tusone emissary to go to the meeting with the Aielund dude for the first time) as Empyre suggests. posts.author: HipRedux

Ahhh... now I see, Empyre.  Tx.  I thought he was just trying to last until the buggy convo would finally trigger but forced into combat somehow.  That sounds a lot like what happens the first time a shifter shifts and then just stands there numb.  Bugged action.

Dunno if this will work or not, but sometimes resting clears out a screwed-up action queue.  If there is a way/place that you can rest before approaching the creature, try that first.  It worked for me in some situations that seemed buggy in various modules.   Resting won't help if a necessary variable didn't get set as it was intended to, though.   Then it's back to a previous save to attempt to restore status quo afresh.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Just a quick FYI, for those who didn't know. Like Bard, Ranger gets an extra 2 skill points per level in Aielund.

I found that at character creation as a Human Ranger with an INT of 14 I got 36 sps to distribute, while expecting 28. Useful if you're planning an Aielund-specific character, and equally useful to know if you're planning on shipping a toon created there elsewhere - 'cos you'll have an illegal build.

Cheers

posts.author: theflyingrodent
posts.content:
The Ancient Aielund Overlord wrote:
History

22 Dec 07

fix: HOTU's crafting junk was broken

10 Dec 07

fix: AB for Epic MC'd chars using DivPower/Tensers
a very small subrange of builds could be shorted a point or two
fix: Prayer and Battletide weren't affecting enemies properly

21 Nov 07

fix: BG Bulls wasn't working properly if cast by NPCs (YABB)
an engine bug seems to make it CL 0 for them, but correct for PCs

07 Nov 07
chg: son of a ... the placeable rule change meant that if you targeted one
with a multi-target spell like Lightning Bolt it wouldn't get damaged
which broke Aielund since the orbs rely on that. i can't win... :P
i've changed it for Lightning Bolt ONLY - you still can't use e.g.
Chain Lightning or Storm Of Vengeance to trigger the orbs.

30 Oct 07
chg: EMS_DURATION_STATBUFF defaults to 10 (10 Rounds, ie 1 Turn per CL)
like it or not, this IS the rule and it's actually a pretty good one
chg: AOEs no longer damage placeables
certain retarded lootable corpse scripts will destroy plot-critical
inventory items if a "corpse" takes any damage. sigh
chg: Flame Strike radius increased to Huge (same as Fireball, Hammer, etc)
Medium is basically single-target in NWN
chg: Mass Blindness/Deafness radius increased to Huge (was Medium)
chg: Negative Energy Burst STR damage is R/L
fix: Negative Energy Burst gave a STR bonus to undead (YABB)
fix: area dispels treated Neutrals as Hostiles on HC+ (YABB)

24 Oct 07
chg: EMS_FF_PC now defaults to -1. IMO, this combined with the difficulty
slider set to HardCore gives the best all-round combination of gameplay:
players are Crittable and risk AOOs on potions just like NPCs, but AOE
spells don't cause game-breaking AI issues.
chg: concealment-vs-ranged in Acid Fog now 25% (was making AAs unplayable)
fix: Holy Sword does not require targeting (2DA, YABB)

12 Sep 07
chg: EMS_ENABLE_PM_STACKING now defaults to on

22 Apr 07
fix: Divine Strength is not dispellable (YABB)

08 Nov 06
chg: area dispels are all Colossal now
chg: Greater Restoration can be used to heal Undead
chg: WOF completely redesigned: BW's and WOTC's are both just horrible
Ld6 Sonic to a max of 15d6, Fort/2; Will Save or be stunned for 1R
chg: WOF can be Amped/Maxed (2DA)
fix: WOF is not Stillable since it's V-only (2DA, YABB)
note that the BW description incorrectly lists it as VS
fix: WOF is centered on the caster and does not require targeting (2DA, YABB)
fix: dispels of Prayer and Battletide are "intent aware"
fix: Greater Restoration is not Extendable (2DA, YABB)
fix: Destruction is ImmunityType:Death and can be Amped/Maxed (2DA, YABB)
fix: Ironguts and HardinessVsPoisons apply to ALL poison-related saves
including unusual spell forms like Cloudkill and Pris Spray

04 Oct 06
add: Confusion is cancelled when combat ends (if the caster died)
it's not technically correct, but it's MUCH less annoying :P
chg: per PHB, confused creatures ALWAYS retaliate if attacked
chg: Bigby 6 Bull Rush is d20+INT+EvoFoci vs d20+STR
chg: Destruction is capped at 20d4
chg: Energy Buffer does not grant Divine DR
chg: Prayer now a Mass Effect rather than a mobile AOE
chg: Battletide now a Mass Effect rather than a mobile AOE
chg: Silence now a Mass Effect rather than a mobile AOE
chg: Invisibility Purge now a Mass Effect rather than a mobile AOE
(mobile AOEs barely work in SP these days, let alone PWs)
chg: Battletide is Category 8 (2DA)
chg: Divine Wrath uses X/+20 DR
chg: Undeath To Death totally rewritten as "Sunburst Lite"
Ld6 Divine to a max of 15d6, Will/2
sorry guys: I know we ALL cheese it, but it was just retardedly uber
chg: Divine Power's Discipline boost is absolute rather than relative
chg: Avengers can't be "lost" by Disarm/Snatch
fix: Shadow Magic (Shades, (Greater)ShadowConjuration) subspell DCs
were still marked as "original" schools (e.g. Evo for CoC)
so they used the Foci from those schools instead of Illusion Foci
(2DA, YABB, thanks Dreu Noctem)
fix: Poison and Contagion had a second saving throw if the first failed
ditto Monster disease/poison bolt/cone Abilities
(BW hacked one into the *application* of poison and disease)
fix: Death Gaze Immunity is (duh) Death, not Negative (2DA, YABB)

28 Sep 06
chg: Epic Metamagic updated for 1.67+
chg: EMS no longer requires a custom IPRP_FEATS.2DA
Premonition no longer grants any bonus feats
Tensers no longer grants Great Cleave
Shapechange no longer grants Great Cleave or IKD
chg: weapon Enhancement+Damage scaling for Tensers matches GMW+FlameWeapon
the weapon now also becomes Keen at casterlevel 16 and above
the weapon is now droppable, which cancels the spell
removing the spell on rest etc no longer needs any mod help
chg: removed Paladin Sequencers - regular ones now work for all classes
chg: EMS_ABJFEATS_AFFECT_DISPEL now defaults to enabled
chg: Mass Protection vs Alignment is now subject to breaches
chg: Grease and Entangle don't fire the Slow VFX for targets with Freedom
chg: Terrifying Rage does not have a +d20 bonus and lasts d4 rounds
fix: Terrifying Rage does not affect creatures immune to fear (YABB)
fix: Extra Music and Lingering Song prereqs (2DA, YABB, thanks Dreu Noctem)
fix: Divine Might/Shield and Extra Turning prereqs (2DA, YABB, thanks Dreu Noctem)

10 Aug 06
chg: rewrote UMD handling to be slightly more generous and elegant:
mixed-caster builds can attempt to use scrolls via any of their classes
rather than just their primary class, e.g. a PAL10/SOR1 now gets to roll
SC for an MA scroll, and a SOR10/PAL1 gets to roll for a Bless scroll, etc.
Scrolls that are Divine-ONLY have no ASF when being cast by a Divine class.
Bards USING (*not* UMDing) scrolls marked as Bard-Usable now use their CHA
to meet the spell's stat requirement, rather than their INT, but *UMD*ing
scrolls that are NOT Bard-Usable still requires INT, same as for Rogues.
chg: Acid Arrow now stops if the target dies

20 Apr 06
add: support for Ioun Stones, no longer dispellable (YABB)
chg: the various weapon damage spells (Darkfire/Clang/etc) no longer stack
chg: AnimalStat and MassAnimalStat buffs no longer stack
chg: removed EMS_DURATION_STATBUFF_MASS: they use EMS_DURATION_STATBUFF too now
chg: Monk Gloves no longer merge for Unarmed Shapes

Terminology

To save confusion:
CHARACTERS have levels. Spells have CLASSES. Fireball is a CLASS 3
spell, learnable by a LEVEL 5 Wizard or a LEVEL 6 Sorc.

R/L means "1 round per caster level". Likewise with T for turn and
H for hour.
10/L means "10 points per caster level"
N/2L means "1 N per 2 caster levels", i.e. +1/5L means +1 for L1-5,
+2 for L6-10, and so on.
(F/2), (R/2), and (W/2) after a spell's damage means a save of that
type for half damage.
A spell with damage listed as e.g. "Ld4 B + Ld4 C(R/2)" means that
ONLY the cold has a Reflex save, and the physical has none.

Anything noted as "Correctly (per BW)" means that a bug was fixed
in BW's implementation relative to THEIR description of the spell:
it may well be that the behaviour is not PHB, and often not even sane,
but that's not the point. :P
It's very common for PHB to say one thing, BW to SAY another, and the
BW code to DO a third. In those situations I've made judgement calls,
generally favouring PHB first, BW's supposed behaviour second, and BW's
actual behaviour last, because frankly they're just not very good at
getting code right.

The damage type abbreviations here are ABCDEFMNPS: Acid, Blunt, Cold, Divine,
Electrical, Fire, Magical, Negative, Positive, Sonic.
The very few spells that do Piercing or Slashing damage (Blade Barrier and a
couple of others) have it spelled out, I hope. :P


************************************************************************

Global Changes
--------------

Spells use real saves. Treating a 1 as a failed save even if you beat
the DC is beyond retarded. Want to kill a 60HD Epic Dragon with a level
11 char? Just Slay Living a couple of times and wait for a 1...
Yes, I know this is the "brilliant" new 3E rule. It's still one of the
most atrocious design decisions in history.

Empower has been bugfixed. In NWN, 2d4 Empowered can be 12: roll 8,
multiply by 1.5. 2d4 Maxed though is always 8. This is pretty clearly
not how things should work.
Empower is now (roll+max)/2, so it's always better than un-Empowered
(which also isn't true in NWN); never better than Maximised; and on
average is exactly the +50% it's supposed to be.

Spell Resistance works correctly. Yes, it's broken in unpatched NWN:
level 11 casters get resisted by SR12. SR checks are now shown as well.
SR against your own spells also works correctly, but is not shown as
it tends to flood the screen if you're in your own AoE's.

Dispels work correctly. This is huge (not to mention unique in NWN. :P)

AoE's work correctly. There is a known bug with ALL non-instant AoE's
in NWN where their SP, DC's, caster level, and metamagic can (usually, do)
become wrong as soon as any other spell is cast. For example, a Cleric
who casts Blade Barrier and then Turns Undead will suddenly discover
that the BB does 0d6 damage.

Spells correctly handle Evasion and Improved Evasion.
Creatures that are stunned, paralyzed, asleep, or petrified don't get
to use Evasion. I mean, ffs. Yes, Evasion is Supernatural, but you're
Helpless. YOU CAN'T MOVE *AT ALL*.

Multi-target homing spells like firebrand and the Isaacs will only hit
visible targets.

The Bigbys will switch to a new enemy once their initial target dies.
The new target must be visible to the caster, as this is a "directed"
attack, not an automatic one.
If the new target succeeds at an SR check, the Bigby is dispelled.
Attempting to control multiple Bigbys of the same class at the same
time reduces the duration of ALL of them because your focus is divided,
and they will all expire when the oldest one does.
While they still don't permit stacking they at least TRY to avoid
completely wasting a second casting, by retargeting themselves if the
original target already has the SAME class of Bigby active on it.
Bigby 8 and 9 now face SR on EACH attack rather than just once. This
avoids the absurd situation where a caster attacked by Bigby 8 gets
stuck in a permanent loop of "Fort Save, fail, stunned for 1 round"
because even a scroll-cast version of the spell is almost impossible
to dispel. This way, if they manage to make the save they can at least
cast a Mantle and absorb the spell on its next attack.

Summons are T/L rather than H/L. You don't need to be a one-man party
all the time if magic actually works.
Summon VII+ correctly now include Earth elementals (BW use d3, oops :P)
Summon I-IX cause a Battle of Wills unless cast from memory, regardless
of the caster's class. If you lose, the creature will go hostile.
Gate causes a Battle of Wills under ANY circumstances. You receive a
+4 bonus if you are have a Protection From Evil, Aura Versus Evil, or
Magic Circle Against Evil in effect, and a -4 penalty if you do not.
Rogues Do Not Gate, and neither does an L3 Wizard with a scroll. :)
Planar Summons do not require a Battle of Wills since the creature
is of your alignment and considers you an ally.
Creating Undead requires a Battle of Wills unless cast from memory.
Fixed an exploit where Munchkins could take a single Cleric level and
the Animal domain to get improved summons as mages/Druids/etc.
Fixed a bug with the various Shadow Conjurations summoning higher
undead than they should (they share the script with Shadowdancers,
so they were just using the casterlevel to determine the creature
rather than the actual SPELL that was cast).

Spells that require a melee touch attack (poison, slay living, etc)
now correctly do the attack BEFORE checking SR.

Charming does not work properly on NPC's at HC and above, so it has
been converted to Daze on those difficulty settings.

UMD no longer sucks (PHB is retarded and BW is even worse).
To use the improved UMD rules, the x2_pc_umdcheck script must be added
to your module separately. It has been moved from the EMS HAK to the
Source Archive because of problems with NWN's search order for scripts:
HAKs inexplicably take priority over module-specific scripts, so it
would otherwise be impossible to override without creating *another* HAK
just to put that in.


************************************************************************

Notes on Families
-----------------

Quite a lot of spells run in "families", i.e. several forms of what is
essentially the same spell, but improving in one way or another as the
class increases. Some of these families are utterly broken.

For example: what do C3 Clarity, C5 Lesser Mind Blank, and C8 Mind Blank
have in common? They're all exactly the same spell, and in a world where
every NPC is Evil they're all massively inferior to the C1 Protection
From Alignment.

On the other hand you have the Elemental DR family, which is
fundamentally solid except for a few small flaws:
C1: Endure: 24H, 10/- to a max of 20
C2: Resist: T/L, 20/- to a max of 30
C3: ProtFrom: 24H, 30/- to a max of 40
C5: EnergyBuffer: T/L, 40/- to a max of 60
It really isn't hard to see what's broken there, is it? :)


************************************************************************

HotU Spells and Weapon Enhancement
----------------------------------

1.62 introduced "temporary item properties" and spells to go with them:
essentially, a way to make weapons +X, Keen, have bonus damage, etc.
None of them work correctly in several important ways.
The damage bonuses are done as spells, which means they don't do xN
damage on crits; they don't activate Cleave if they cause a kill; and
they can't ever be Dispelled. They also stack with each other, with
a weapon's existing bonuses, etc: i.e. you can have a sword that does
2d6 Fire damage "naturally", and also 1d6+5 Darkfire and 1d4+10 Flame
Weapon, for a grand total of up to 37! bonus damage on every hit. That's
not counting Divine Might and Divine Favor, Bless Weapon, etc, which can
take the bonus to over 60.
As usual, most also have implementation bugs on top of everything else:
e.g. Darkfire is supposed to go up to +10, but BW never could get math
right. :P

I'm repairing these as time goes by, generally by changing the damage
to fixed amounts (this is required by NWN engine limitations) based on
caster level and fixing the stacking issues.

Elemental Shield
As of 1.62, the OnHit retaliation is NOT OnHit, it's On*Damaged*
which is a completely different situation and far less desirable.
You have d4 HD. If you have to TAKE damage to DEAL damage, guess
who's going to die first?
BW have said it's highly unlikely they will ever fix this, so
I've increased its duration to 2R/L so it delivers something
resembling the number of retaliations overall that it used to.
Damage has been split to 1d6+L/2 points of each of Fire and Cold.
This is very slightly more damage than before, but also less damage
overall against creatures with elemental DR.
Note that OnHit retaliation ignores metamagic. Not a big deal here
since the majority of its damage comes from caster level anyway.

Enervation
Per PHB does NOT have a Fort Negates save

Evard's Black Tentacles
Duration now correctly (per PHB and even BW) R/L.
Per PHB, creatures inside the tentacles move at half speed.
Per PHB, there is no Fort save: you either resist the grapple or you
don't. You are also NOT paralyzed, merely immobilized.
The "grapple check" math is now correct and scales with the caster,
and is also a true grapple. BW just had it as 5+d20 vs AC, which is
why this spell has generally been considered a joke: the tentacles
couldn't "hit" most creatures on anything except a 20.
Per BW, the tentacles are +2 "weapons", so GV etc will NOT reduce
the damage inflicted by them.
Unlike BW, attacks are NOT combined, so DR is applied correctly.

Fear
Per PHB is Will Partial, not Negates: a successful save leaves the
target Shaken for 1R. Caster is immune since this is supposed to
be a cone emanating from them, not a generic splat.

Ice Storm
No save is nice, but, erm, it's weaker than fireball even when

The caster causes giant hailstones to fall from the sky onto
targets in a Huge area, to a maximum of 1 per caster level.
Enemies nearest the epicenter are struck first.
Each hailstone does 1d4B and 1d4C per 2L, with no save.
All creatures in the area NOT directly struck by the hail,
including the caster and her allies, are not Bludgeoned
and get (R/2) for the Cold.
