Chain Lightning
This spell's design is fundamentally flawed.
Secondary damage needs to be at least 10d6 rather than L/2 d6.
An L12 caster does 12d6 primary but only 6d6 secondary under the
original spell, whereas the standard Lightning Bolt will do 10d6
to all targets. Realistically speaking, Chain is SIGNIFICANTLY
WEAKER than Bolt despite being 3 classes higher, and even worse
off when compared to a C3 Fireball which doesn't have LOS
restrictions.
Given that this spell has to compete for slots with IGMS; Tenser's;
the Greater forms of Breach, Dis, and Stoneskin; Ethereal Visage,
and more (C6 has by FAR the best combination of spells overall,
arguably more so than even the C9's) there is simply no point in
this spell even existing, as it is today.
Considering that a Cone of Cold does 15d6 to ALL its targets and
is a class LOWER, there is no justification for Chain being so much
less effective. Damage is Ld6 to ALL targets now, but capped at 10d6
for secondary targets. This preserves the "spirit" of the original
spell, but without the crippling defect.

Circle of Death
AoE is correctly Colossal rather than Large.
Correctly doesn't try to slay constructs.

Flesh to Stone
Correctly fails against creatures with Stoneskin. :)

Legend Lore
This rather pathetic spell (erm, HALF the bonus of Identify? Huh?) has
been completely overhauled.
If cast on yourself it functions as the BW version, except that you
receive the full bonus to Lore rather than half.
If cast on an item though, it does something rather fun... :)
You study a single item intensively, with the intent of divining and
possibly altering some of its magical properties.
The degree of success is determined by your caster level and any
relevant bonuses (ability modifier, Divination focus, etc) against a
base DC of 11 plus the item's value in KGP
DC11: the item is successfully identified, regardless of its value
DC $: you make the item usable by your class
DC $+2: you make the item usable by any class
DC $+5: you make the item usable by your race
DC $+7: you make the item usable by any race
DC $+10: you make the item usable by your alignment
DC $+12: you make the item usable by any alignment
This spell does not in any way alter the mundane properties of the item:
a suit of Full Plate is still Heavy Armour, and cannot be equipped unless
you have the requisite proficiency no matter how you alter its magical
properties

Tenser's Transformation
Per PHB, plus the caster is given a Greatsword of the appropriate level
since it's retarded to expect them to lug one around just for this.
(Gnomes and Halflings get a Longsword).
L11: +2, 1d6 M
L14: +3, 1d6 M
L16: +4, 1d6 M
L18: +5, 1d6 M
These values will let the caster equip the item even if ILR is on.
The bonus damage is M rather than F, as it just makes more sense.
There is a known but minor issue with resting while Transformed:
you will be left with the GS (although it will have become mundane
at least) unless the module actually advances the game clock, which
standard NWN does not.
If you are using these scripts in your own module, calling
SpecialisedDispel(OBJECT_SELF, SPELL_TENSERS_TRANSFORMATION) in the
OnPlayerRest script will also take care of the problem.

Power Word Stun
Like all spells, this wasn't designed to function at epic levels.
As a result, it becomes less useful than even the C1 Color Spray,
which CAN stun a 22HD creature.
Thanks to the THP bug, Enervation and even EnergyDrain don't help.
The HP limit basically makes it yet ANOTHER "Fort Negates" spell,
like EVERYTHING above the C5 Hold Monster is. gg Fighter-only NWN.
So here's how you fix it:
You can stun up to 10HP per caster level for 1d4 rounds. For every
50pts over you are, you get an extra 1d4 rounds.
See how easy that was? :)

Class 8

Blackstaff
This is the worst spell in history. Completely redesigned.
You bring a shimmering stafflike plane of force into existence,
similar to Mr Pointy. The staff's attack bonus is equal to your
caster level plus your INT/CHA bonus, with an additional +4
enhancement bonus. It deals 1d6+4 points of damage per hit,
with a threat range of 20 and a critical multiplier of x2.
The staff is a significantly inferior combatant to Mr Pointy,
but makes 2 attacks per round rather than 1, and on a successful
hit will attempt to Dispel Magic on the target, at your caster
level.
The staff cannot be harmed by physical attacks, but is subject
to Dispel Magic, Dismissal, Banishment, etc. For Dismissal, the
staff's Will save is the Will save of its creator at the time of
the staff's creation.

Gate

Meteor Swarm
This is supposed to be Ice Storm's big brother, but it's LESS
effective. It doesn't scale with the caster; it has an R/2 save
that translates to no damage for Evaders and 10d6 *at best* for
ImprovedEvaders.
Creatures within 6ft take no damage? Players move nearly 60ft
in the time between you casting a spell and it actually firing.
Where the hell do you think the guy ATTACKING me is by then?!
It's just terribly designed, plain and simple.
The caster causes giant meteors to fall from the sky onto
targets in a Colossal area, to a maximum of 1 per caster level.
Enemies nearest the epicenter are struck first.
Each meteor does 1d4B and 1d4F per L, with no save.
All creatures in the area NOT directly struck by the meteors,
EXCLUDING the caster herself but including her allies,
are not Bludgeoned and get (R/2) for the Fire.
Yes, I know that's 40d4 at level 20. Wilting is 20d8 and a
class lower, and not subject to DR.

Mordenkainen's Disjunction
Has so many bugfixes I couldn't list them all.
In a nutshell, it works correctly now: every case, every combination.

Always removes all temporary weapon properties (Darkfire etc) regardless

See the notes at the end of this file for some evil new functionality

Power Word Kill
Same basic design problem as PWS. Here's how you fix it:
You can kill up to 6HP per caster level.

Shapechange
Too many fixes and improvements to list. It no longer totally sucks,

Weird

************************************************************************

Epic Spells
-----------

Such a farce. The whole "Epic Magic" desperately needs some actual DESIGN
effort put into it, but here are quick fixes for the two offensive spells.

Save DC is now CASTER level plus caster bonus. Even DEX 8 Clerics can make
the Reflex save on Hellball under the stock rules, because Epic Spells have
LOWER DC's than normal spells.
They can also benefit from PHB Metamagic now.

Hellball
Uses all 5 elemental damage types rather than 4, but is still pathetic.


************************************************************************

Divine Abilities
----------------

Turn Undead

Creatures that have already been turned are no longer turned over and
over again. This is a huge benefit: since turning has a HD limit, those
creatures continue to drain HD from the cleric's total turning ability
under the BW implementation, thereby stopping multiple turnings from
actually affecting any new or stronger creatures.

Turned creatures have their movement speed halved. This is more a case
of fixing bugs than anything else:
If you're attacking something with a fear effect in NWN, the game tends
to move you close to the target, then stop you, then move the creature
away, so you never actually get to ATTACK it even if you're hasted
and it's a zombie. Even worse is that creatures that are knocked down
magically spring up and run away, and it's just SO annoying.


Divine Might/Shield

Are now correctly Supernatural, which stops them being removed by Dispels

Class 6

Harm
Per PHB inflicts up to 10HP/L and is capped at 150HP.
Under normal circumstances, Harm will never kill a creature:
if the damage caused would be fatal the creature is reduced to 1HP
instead. However, targets that are unusually susceptible to
Negative Energy may in fact be killed.
Note that Harm DOES have a save: it's Will for half damage, same
as every other "Inflict XYZ Wounds" attack.
Munchkin Clerics are going to hate me forever... :(

Heal
Per PHB cures up to 10HP/L and is capped at 150HP.
Removes all harmful effects that Restoration can, as well as Disease
and Poison.
Correctly gives an Amp bonus (+50%) to Clerics with the Healing domain.
Correctly has W/2 when used as an attack on undead.


Class 7

Destruction
Same as everything else: spells that don't scale with the caster are
fundamentally bad design, especially when you're talking about 10d6
damage even when it's a Rogue using a scroll. There isn't really a
good way to fix this without nerfing it for real casters too though,
so damage is now d4 per level with no cap.

Greater Restoration
As Heal, but also removes Charm, Confusion, Curse, Daze, Domination,
Fear, Slow, Stun, and true permanent negative levels (i.e. ones caused
by an Energy Drain - this is the ONLY way to remove such negative levels
other than a successful dispel against them) and is capped at 200HP.
Note that it can NOT be used as an attack against Undead.

Word of Faith
I'm not really sure how this ended up so utterly broken. I think it's
because the Luskan Captains in CH4 cast it a lot, so it was hacked up
specifically for the OC.
Correctly (per PHB WoC, and BW themselves even!) does NOT blind.
Correctly per PHB WoC gives summoned creatures a W-4(N) save.
Correctly does NOT banish MrPointy (a plane of force is not a creature).
Correctly per PHB WoC applies the effects based on RELATIVE level
rather than absolute.

Druid Spells
------------

If you're wearing metal armour, which is anything other than Cloth or
Light, any spell you attempt to cast will AUTOMATICALLY FAIL.
I don't care that BW incorrectly gave you Medium Armour proficiency,
or that you can MC to Fighter and run around in Full Plate with no
side-effects. EMS is about fixing bugs, and that's a bug. Deal with it.
You're lucky you don't lose all spellcasting for 24 hours, which is
the real rule.


Class 1

Charm Animal
Is not the same as Charm Person
Correctly is considered a hostile action
Duration raised to R/L


Class 2

Barkskin
Per PHB is 1+1/3L. Still H/L, though it should really be T/L


Class 3

Call Lightning
Correctly only targets visible enemies
Correctly only targets one enemy per level, to a max of 10
(Placeables are freebies, because I'm kind and unlocking/bashing
them is dull as hell)

Infestation of Maggots
Duration is correctly R/2L
Correctly requires a successful melee touch attack
Unlike all the other broken HOTU "single-cast" spells, this one is
STAYING single-cast, because it's a retarded Munchkin spell.
It should probably be changed to just deal damage instead.
Can no longer reduce CON below 4 or kill the target: it's absolutely
outrageous to give creatures Death Spells this early.

Quillfire
Another BW spell, another disaster.
This is the same class as Poison. It does Poison AND damage.
Seriously, does anybody there even PRETEND to design this stuff?!
Now requires a ranged touch attack; damage type is piercing; damage
is d8+L/2 with the cap removed; and there is no poison.

Spike Growth
Correctly checks for SPIKE GROWTH effects to avoid stacking, BW checks
for Greater Magic Fang. Way to use constants guys. :P
Duration dropped to R/L: permanent AOE's, which is essentially what
this is, are incredibly bad for the engine.
Duration of Movement Speed Decrease dropped to 1 Turn: PHB says the
effect is removed by any Cure spell, so anyone would simply drink a
Cure Minor and be rid of it immediately. NWN requires Restoration,
which is far too "expensive" for such a low-level spell.


Class 5

Inferno
Behaves more like Combust: the target gets a Reflex save each round
to negate the spell; the damage is 1 point per caster level to a max
of 15; and it can be cast at a target more than once.

Owl's Insight
Removed


Class 6

Crumble
Genuinely has no SR

Drown
Typical BW-created disastrous excuse for a spell.
Nothing should EVER do stupid things like "90% of HP". It's the same
crap as BW's Harm: take a 700HP Ancient Dragon and instantly turn it
into a Goblin with a retarded Munchkin spell.
Reimplemented as 1d6 per caster level to a max of 15d6 or half the
target's current HP, whichever is lower; and F/2 rather than Negates.
Also fixes a bug in BW's where the damage was susceptible to DR.


Class 7

Creeping Doom
Correctly has no SR (BW has SR on first round but not others)
Correctly has no movement speed decrease (BW's constant copy+paste
from Acid Fog means virtually every AOE they did has that... :P)
Correctly per PHB is constant damage per round (1 point per level)
not BW's retarded scaling damage, and has no damage limit.
Stop whining you sadcase Munchkins: if this was a REAL implementation,
it would be 20 bites at 1 damage each, so any amount of DR would negate
the entire thing.


Class 8

Bombardment
Really shouldn't have SR or a save, but it's BW's creation so blame them.
Note that contrary to the description, the damage is actually capped at
10d8 rather than 20d8; and it targets ALL creatures, not just enemies.
I've raised the cap to 15d8 and left the rest of it unchanged.

Nature's Balance
SR drop works correctly

Premonition
Druids cannot cast this spell, and never should have been able to.
It makes no sense at all, and was a side-effect of BW turning
Magical Foresight into just "Even Greater Stoneskin".


Class 9

Elemental Swarm
4T/L rather than 24H


************************************************************************

Bard Spells
-----------

Class 4

War Cry
Damage bonus now Sonic rather than Slashing: so many things have DR for
physical damage that it basically doesn't do anything otherwise, and this
is one of the very few Bard spells that doesn't utterly suck to begin with.
Also, the Fear effect has been raised from a constant 4R to R/L, and
creatures who succeed at the Will save are still shaken for 1R.


************************************************************************

Monster Spell-Abilities
-----------------------

Virtually all of BW's monster abilities are broken: defective math,
wrong creature, wrong duration, missing save, wrong DC, etc etc.
Fixed so far: auras, gazes, howls, cones, tyrant fog zombie / ghast,
bolts.
Not fixed yet: pulses, dragons (aura, breath, wingblast),
krenshar, salt mephit, steam mephit, stink beetle.
Howls now correctly do not penetrate zones of Silence.

Petrification spells and abilities now fail against creatures with
Stoneskin. The combination of the defective 1=autofail saves, no SR,
ignoring mantles, and no immunity to petrification meant that just
2 or 3 basilisks in a room was a guaranteed death, even for L40 chars.
Cockatrice Petrification Touch Attacks now NEED TO SUCCEED AT A
TOUCH ATTACK FIRST. BW scripts suck SO much. >:(

Hell Hound Breath now scales with the creature and has R/2 save.


************************************************************************

Other Stuff
-----------

Familiars

Auldar's uberpanther has been replaced with a ShadowDancer. If you want a
Power-Attacking, KD'ing, 10d6 Sneak Attack killing machine you should be
using Summon Creature. The panther is also now your level rather than +1.
Per PHB, familiars get their master's Will Save (if it's higher, and it
would be shocking if it wasn't).
Can only be fed once an hour, and only heal Ld6 HP. Giving them a full heal
whenever you feel like it is an exploit. If you can't take better care of
them you deserve to pay for the potions. To compensate, and to remove the
annoyance of having to micromanage their health, they now regenerate 1HP/R:
it won't keep them alive longer in combat, but it means that low-level mages
don't have to constantly re-feed after every fight, or use potions that they
can't afford.

There are some optional enhancements in the EMS *source* archive that have
been left out of the HAK as updates to the Pausanias AI could potentially
break them: a "scout ahead" command in the familiar's conversation, and
a command to use Shadow Evade (panther familiar, level 5 or higher). These
are in nw_g_fam.dlg. There is also a fix to the henchscout.nss script to
stop scouts from teleporting across the map.
Note that if you're building a mod that uses both the Pausanias HAK and
the EMS HAK, you MUST give EMS priority, as the Pausanias AI contains two
spell scripts (dismissal and banishment) that use BioWare's defective SR
and saving throw routines.


Shadow Evade
Is now correctly Supernatural, which stops it being removed by Dispels
Lasts 5 or DEXMOD rounds, whichever is higher
AC also increases by 1 per 5L after 10


************************************************************************

Additional Notes
----------------

Mordenkainen's Disjunction has an option to enable actual PHB-style
disjunction. VERY cool stuff.

If you set the ModuleInt "EMS_DISJOIN_TIME", Morks may disjoin magic
items for that many rounds. The chance of this happening is your
caster bonus vs d100, for EACH equipped item on the target.
Unlike PHB, these effects occur only on targeted castings rather
than for all items in the area.
This is the only way a Mage has ANY chance in PvP with all the uber
items and Munchkin Belts of Immunity to Everything Magic EVAH!!!11!
Castings from scrolls have a 0 bonus, and thus cannot destroy items.
The recommended duration is 10 rounds, i.e. the same length of time
as the SR drop that Mord's causes; the default duration is 0, because
by default the Int does not exist.
If you set the value to -1, any disjoined items will be IRREVOCABLY
DESTROYED.

This is really just intended for PvP play, but I would LOVE to see an
SP mod use it sometime... :P
Thats quite extensive, will require some reading!

posts.author: theflyingrodent
posts.content:
In a nutshell, it looks like: Lots of spell changes, Druids cant wear Medium Armour without lots of spellcasting penalties, Bards and Rangers get +2 Skill Points, Bard Song's a bit different but does more AB now, bards get a ton of new spells, Bards get Rogue Proficiency.

Am very tempted to make a bard, but something like the Bearded Battlemage could be fun with all the new spellchanges.

Lots to ponder! But probably won't have the time until January. Fooey.



Edit: Another Question:
Is it possible to change alignment easily in this module? Or out of the question?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I shall continue in my mission of unhelpfulness, concerning alignment changes this time.

I've never consciously tried to change alignment - I've struggled to maintain it at times, though. There are plenty of responses you can give that trigger shifts to Evil, Lawful, Good, etc (helpfully, the conversation box will inform you which response triggers which effect - for those with litlle grasp of morality and ethics), as well as shifts according to actions. You'll be warned if you're getting close to changing alignment and its incumbent loss of class abilities, so it should be impossible to become a baby-skewering pally (for example).

However, if you're talking about cheats, I've no idea.

posts.author: theflyingrodent
posts.content:
I meant without cheats yeah. I remember in the OC it was possible to go from good to evil or vice versa if you did the right quests/got rewards in certain ways. Was curious as to whether this was similar.

Looking through the forum posts here it looks like there's a fake EMS hakpack you can install to bypass all the new spell changes. I'm tempted to do that but at the same time, the module was probably designed with the changes in mind.

Anyway! I'm specifically wondering if there's a way to go from good to evil easily [or at least neutral], without cheating, because that would open the door somewhat for a particular build possibility.

Preferably around the teen levels. Yes that is a very specific question and I'll probably have to find the answer to it myself, but what the hey. :P

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
My best guess is that, provided your starting class - ie, non-prestige - isn't hampered by having to be at a particular place on the Good-Evil axis, and you haven't already taken another pre-determined class, you should be fine: there are plenty of opportunities to shift alignment in Part 2 (which, essentially, takes you through your teen years - certainly level 10-18). So, for example, you could start off as a good Monk, take some Rogue, then at level 14 commit yourself to a career as an Assassin by being naughty in advance of your next levelling-up. But you couldn't start in the same way, then take some Pally, then take Assassin, without losing your Pally privileges.

I could be wrong, but that's what seems logical to me (as far as logic goes in these circumstances).

Just as a suggestion, why not try a playthough "as is" first, then decide if you want/need to bugger around with the spells?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I seem to recall someone asking about whether there's an xp penalty to travelling with companions a while ago (please don't tell me I've started dreaming questions), and having just started a new run through Aielund I thought I'd check it out, and no, there isn't. Tried the first few challenges in Chapter 1 both solo and with henchies, and the xp was constant, so hurrah!

However, interestingly enough, for the first time, retrieving the mayor's documents from the naughty halfling lass in Bracksworth didn't trigger an attack: she just got a bit huffy, but no violence. Wulgar Ironbow is clearly a force not to be trifled with - even at level 1! (That was in the "with companions" encounter.) That said, it was a little annoying not to get the xp and coin (I know it's minuscule amounts in the grand scheme, but early on little things matter) - so I popped back in to see if she'd changed her mind and wanted a ruck, but no, still merely grumpy (and, playing LG, it just wouldn't feel right killing her anyway).

Cheers

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Hmm. I never knew that was an option, getting those document without her attacking. Does Wulgar have a good score in Bluff, Persuade, or Intimidate? One of those might have had an effect, or you might have gotten a lucky roll on one of those.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Well, I did play around a little with Hip's skills allocation, so Wulgar got 2 ranks in Persuade at creation (he'll be getting some Harper Scout later, so would need the points anyway). Perhaps that was it, although the convo seemed to follow its previous pattern - I play nice, Dante threatens, end of. I wondered if it was a glitch, but she responded after recovery of the documents (saying something like, "I see you've found them, now please leave my home."). Maybe your Persuasive Archer will get the same when you get the chance to take him/her out for a spin.

posts.author: Stagmeister

I hadn't noticed before, because I'd just taken it as a given he'd be Ranger throughout. Responsive AI? Unless something's gone a bit buggy, that is. Interesting, though.

posts.author: HipRedux

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thus far, I've used Dante as my frontline whacker with his 2-handed sword, while I've been practising Wulgar's archery in the main. At the next level-up (6), My intention was to open his options by giving him autonomy to decide which form of attack he'd prefer at the time (the AI has worked very well with that previously). At that stage, I'll have both WS feats, PBS and Rapid Shot, so can be more adaptable myself. But I'll have to check whether his feats have improved his bowmanship as they would normally have done, or whether he's gone on a different tangent (I noticed he didn't take WS at Fighter 4, so we'll just have to wait and see). I already have Nellise (Cleric 5) making her own choices, but this will stop soon, and I'll have her concentrate on her crossbow attacks, buffing and other spelly things.

Don't get me wrong, this isn't a complaint, just something different. I'm having to manage myself differently with Wulgar, so I suppose it makes sense to be doing the same with my team. The only annoying thing is that by the time I've got these henchies mastered (level 9) I'll have to swap them for a different pair. Hey-ho.

BTW, Hip, I've tweaked Wulgar's skills distribution a little (not the totals for each skill, just the order I'm taking them), taking all the Lore points early - handy not paying for identification when money's tight - along with enough Spellcraft to net me a +1 v Spells pre-epic and a few earlier Persuade ranks. It means Listen suffers a little, but I know my henchies (or thought I did!), and they can compensate for that.

EDIT: Quick update. Just deaded wyverns and gone to level 6. Dante continues to level as Fighter. And what feat did he take? Great-bloody-Cleave. This, when he's sitting on PBS but no WF (let alone WS) in longbow. Idiot. Mind you, with his Fighter levels, I can now kit him in some good heavy armour. Swings and roundabouts, eh?

EDIT 2: Blow me down - I'm spectacularly avatared! Thanks for the "how-to-not-be-so-thick" instructions!

EDIT 3: Now at level 7, and what's he picked as his Fighter bonus feat? Imp Initiative. Luvverly. Oh, and I'm pleased to be away from page 13 of this thread. Rodent's monumental citation is very useful, but it does strain the poor old eyes!

posts.author: Empyre65

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I agree, he's very good with his 2-hander, it's just that previously I've felt the need to be more of a physical presence up front and personal, so I'd give him the shooty option, at which he was also very good. That wasn't the issue, though, it was the levelling in Fighter that I'd never seen before (my suspicion is that he'll return to pure Ranger for future encounters).

Still, for now, he's in the statue's armour as we head to the Exiled Kinght's tomb (saved me a small fortune in not having to buy the geared-up Ranger armour). Being a dwarf, I get to wear Dorum MacTavish's gear, and Nell's in the gear with the pretty blue smock on it.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: I know I shouldn't be surprised, but I am. Wulgar is a great shootist. I'd never contemplated taking a ranged attacker as my toon before primarily because I'd never seen one able to get more than a couple of shots off before being battered. But hells, no - this stocky wee fella inspires you to trust him. I'm hardly ever feeling like I have to do a hatchet job, now - which, as a natural-born meleer takes some doing. Currently at level 9 (and yes, Dante continues as Fighter - having taken Imp Power Attack and Imp Crit: GSword at the previous 2 levels. I suppose 1 decent feat from 2 isn't too shabby. Still no WS, though) and about to spring Criosa. So, edging towards the Chapter 1 finale...

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
There is another slightly-less thematic version of Wulgar I've played, Stagmeister.  It addresses an issue I've run into in certain environments.  Dunno if this saga has any of this but I can nudge you in the right direction if you decide to trot out Wulgar in another arena sometime.

The problem centers on opposed archers.  Many times designers will equip their archers with greater archer belts.  That really bothers Wulgar because now he must stash the bow, grab the axe and charge the nest.  That was the main reason for an alternate slashing attack.  But there's another way.

Instead of WF: handaxe, focus in sling.  You'll be able to reap all the benefits of the bow's feats, PBS, Rapid Shot. etc.  The difference is that it will be bludgeoning damage against those blasted fortified archers so will bypass their damage resistance (better vs. skels as well).  Plus you'll have a tower shield in the other hand to help ward off counterattacks.  Dunno if you noticed it or not, but bullets seem to always have much different enhancements than arrows do.  I particularly like the bullets that cast slowness with acid (Fool's Gold or some such??) and the screamers that combine sonic damage with silence spams (not bad vs. casters).  Those have bailed me out of sticky situations several times. But there is always a cost, right?  The finessed handaxe will suffer a 3AB loss but it's still quite unusual to have a decent attack with piercing, slashing AND bludgeoning damage. It's important to retain KD vs. mages else they will match your artillery with some nasty ranged stuff of their own.

But without the axe being part of the character's background, it just doesn't seem right somehow.  Wulgar has a tale to tell and chucking stones at passers-by was never part of it.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks for that Hip. I am trying to maintain Wulgar's integrity - thought it only fair. I will confess to having some qualms about what he'll do when it comes to the Iron Lord and his golem army at the end of chapter 3 (around level 23/24), but if I'm to keep faith I'll have to ignore that until I come upon it (though I'll be trying to formulate a strategy while I go on). I had contemplated taking mace rather than handaxe, but decided his back-story made a compelling case for hatchet, and iirc there are some arrows that also inflict bludgeoning damage somewhere (serves me right for not paying much attention to ranged stuff in the past). Electrical damage would also prove beneficial.

Anyway, there's a long road to travel before we get to that stage...

posts.author: Stagmeister

Normally, my party takes at least one casualty in that encounter, but this time no one dropped below 50% of their hit points, and Wulgar was untouched. We even had most of our support troops intact (who then insisted on following us around like lost puppies). I could get to like this ranged malarkey!

Almost at level 10 and off to the big bad city with the princess now...

Thanks Hip. Okay, I tried it with curved brackets, and that didn't work at all, so I deleted it. So, here goes with squared ones. No idea what I'll do if that doesn't work.

Arrows available in Chapter 1

Spoiler [+]

Loot
99 Arrows+2 - +2 piercing
99 Acid Arrows - +1d6 acid
99 Lightning Arrows - +1d6 electrical
24 Piercing Arrows - +1d6 piercing. More may be available, but I can't remember if I got them from a chest or a corpse.

EDIT: Don't know if editing inside the spoiler would balls it up, so erred on the side of caution. If it helps, the best longbow in Chapter 1 is the Fine Composite Longbow (got during the poacher quest) - 1d8, crit x3, massive crits 3 damage, mighty +5.

EDIT 2: Sorry, I suppose one could argue that the longbow+1 is a better bow (although, technically, it's the oriental variation, available from Rubo in Culdeny), and it probably is as far as AB is concerned, but overall I'd go for the aforementioned Fine Composite, where a hit actually means something (more so if you're wearing at least some STR gear in Wulgar's case) and you don't run out of shafts before your foe drops. I know I was hitting for plenty of 12s and 13s worth of damage (and many c30 crits) with normal arrows during the Battle for Culdeny (at Fighter level 9 wearing Ogre Power mittens - thus STR 16). I'll always try with mundane stuff in my first go at a "difficult" encounter, just to see if I actually need to expend my expensive gear - and a lot of the time, I don't. Apologies, this edit is taking over the posting now.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
:)
Just experiment with it and get used to how it works. Just start with a save that you can return to if you need to. Find a safe place where you can leave your company behind.
Use stealth. Attack and hide immediately in plain sight. Let things calm down. If the paralysis succeeds, move to your next target and repeat. When all are paralysed, you can break cover and complete the kills.
Beware that you cannot hide when in combat. You have to stop the attack before you hide. I do that by assigning the attack icon from the circle menu to a hotkey. I do the same with the stealth icon. I press the two hotkeys is quick succession to abort attack and hide.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: You might enjoy this, Mick. Just tried out your suggestion in the main room of Fairloch's Assassins' Guild. First go was an abject failure, but killed 'em all at second time of asking. It would appear that assassins are easy to assassinate!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Well, Wulgar's just arrived back in Fairloch and is about to have a chat with Sparky.

A concern I'd had about his sojourn with the undead was around weapon effectiveness, and for the first time I had Desmond give me an enchantment - my Predator bow got unlimited +1 Arrows ( for a 50k bill) - before setting out. As it later transpired, this was as much a curse as a blessing, because it wouldn't let me subsequently load acid arrows against the Dark Lord (Lich henchman), so I might be stuck with +1 arrows with that bow, dagnab it.

Anyway, and this speaks to the quality of the build - and, to be fair, the quality of the hench AI - that I only felt the need to switch to handaxe and shield once during the whole episode - when I opened a door just to say an immediate hello to a bone golem. However, as soon it was dispatched I zipped inside to give the others access while I gave full peppering from range. I will say that I hate those Abysmal (sorry, Abyssal) Spectres - however useful they may be for xp. Poor old Ronan got deaded several times, although he wasn't helped by the fact that Sir William (first problem I've had with the Pally) took so damn long prepping himself unnecessarily. They're undead - just go Turn and Smite, you clown! Sorry, it's just that where I thought he'd shine, he didn't. Half the time, fights were over before he was fully ready to enter the fray.

Okay, it's Pity's turn now (my Kama-Shinobi). Should be a very different experience...

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:
A concern I'd had about his sojourn with the undead was around weapon effectiveness, and for the first time I had Desmond give me an enchantment - my Predator bow got unlimited +1 Arrows ( for a 50k bill) - before setting out. As it later transpired, this was as much a curse as a blessing, because it wouldn't let me subsequently load acid arrows against the Dark Lord (Lich henchman), so I might be stuck with +1 arrows with that bow, dagnab it.
That's a rookie archer burp.  Now that you've gotten over it, your choices will prove more "far-sighted".  Diverse ammo enhancements are probably the #1 reason to go ranged attack, but VERY expensive ("archers" and "deep pockets" are synonymous).  Crafting unlimited onto a more pedestrian bow with a decent +enhancement would serve the purpose you intended... a back-up resource to rely upon when you run out of the expensive ammo.
Poor old Ronan got deaded several times, although he wasn't helped by the fact that Sir William (first problem I've had with the Pally) took so damn long prepping himself unnecessarily. They're undead - just go Turn and Smite, you clown! Sorry, it's just that where I thought he'd shine, he didn't. Half the time, fights were over before he was fully ready to enter the fray.
Sounds a lot like the potential problem with Aribeth in HotU.  Can't you turn off the self-buffing and autohealing through convo or some setting ("I will trust to my blade.")?

Indeed. I had thought about reloading a save prior to ballsing-up, but decided to bite the bullet. A shame in some ways, Predator is a great bow - certainly the best longbow in chapter 2 (comp lbow +3, Mighty+4, Massive Crits 1d10, Woodland Stride). I've kept it with me into Chapter 3 (I'll confess that I also invested 30k in its giving me 16 SR) as my "ordinary" bow, and purchased a comp lbow +4, Mighty +5 (not available in Chapter 2) for my cache of "special" arrows. I'm sure something else will come up, but this seemed like a reasonable compromise for now.

My current problem is that Robert Black is my only melee support. I'm sure Criosa would be willing (mad thing that she is) to assist, but throwing a single rapier-using Rogue/Wiz into the heart of battle seems ill-considered at best (leaving aside the fact that she's the princess I've promised to keep safe). I'm not letting Robert dual-wield currently - first, because it's a sod that he wields bastard swords; and second, because I want him as AC-heavy as I can get him. This, naturally, means I'm not as AC protected as I'd like to be, but DwD is very helpful with that in a tight spot, such as the duergar mobs we've just been playing with in Stoneguard, and things will improve markedly when I hit level 22 and get some Tumble kicking in (sorry, Hip, I delayed HS1 by 1 level for an extra Tumble AC point). Of course, before that stage I'll have to decide whether to give Robert the speedy armour or not, because I'll be wearing better DEX (thus AC) gear by then (probably at level 20).

I digress, sorry. Yes, you can modify the Pally's prep as you suggest - I just forgot to do it. D'oh. Although, to be fair, they both disregarded me completely when I told them to defend me and not attack until I did, so who knows what would have happened. However, Sir William proved an excellent companion in the assault on the palace, so all was grand.

You might have noticed that I haven't reported back on the Kama-Shinobi. That's because I got it horribly wrong. Several times. I will get there, but I think a few wet towels on the head are needed first, so I'll get Wulgar and co. back to Culdeny before I attempt it again - sorry, Mick.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Now that I have updated my Aielund Saga, I thought I might try documenting the differences I notice. If there are too many differences, I might have to abandon this attempt.

The first thing I noticed is that the traveler's attire I start with has a backpack instead of a cloak.
Nelise has a different portrait and head.
I like that the dialog options that affect alignment now say so.
Killing the cunning wolf that was threatening the cows (and the fake cow) now awards experience points.
The area immediately South of Bracksworth looks very different (and better), using a different tileset. Also, the monsters there are now wolves instead of kobalds.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Excellent idea, Empyre. It'll be fascinating to see the differences.

Frankly, so early in the story, not giving xp for that cunning wolf was just mean. Oh, and I don't recall seeing any kobolds throughout the saga.

I get what you say about the alignment-affecting dialogs, except it's a pig of a thing that you get 50xp for whichever option you choose as well as the 1pt shift - be it Lawful, Chaotic, Good or Evil - because you get zip xp with a Neutral response, and NG is my preferred option (given the choice). In Culdeny (in chapter 1, anyway), when I find I've drifted a little far from my 50 on the lawful-neutral-chaotic axis I just pop down into the crypt and take something from a tomb, which triggers a 1pt shift to chaotic each time. This means I can give a few lawful responses for the xp, all of which helps early on, and then go re-balance myself. What's also nice about the xp for such responses is that even when you hit the 100%, rendering the shifts useless, you still get the 50xp, so still handy.

In my current excursion, trying to finalize my re-tooling of GDL's Hearth Guard, I suspect we're running about level so far. I've recently said hello to the wyverns and am on my way back up, having just hit level 6.

Hope you're able to continue with your documentation

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
The road north of Bracksworth and the Calespur Mountains all look the same as before, but Culdeny looks totally different. Before, Culdeny's buildings had the same style as Bracksworth. The interiors mostly look the same, except the church and the ships. The Calespur Ranges looks more subtly different, with the biggest change being the shack where the lead poacher is.

EDIT: In the cave in the Calespur Ranges where there are now a wyvern and some smaller wyverns, there used to be a young adult black dragon and some black dragon hatchlings, and the barrier and the ballista look different.

posts.author: Empyre65

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I wasn't sure whether to post this here or on the screenshots thread, but thought that was probably more for, well, screenshots...

@ Empyre: I see you have both Ronan and Sir William with your Persuasive Archer in Fairloch. I'm assuming you'll be using Ronan for his trapping/unlocking skills and leaving him as a sneaker in combat. I confess that I forgot he was a shortsword specialist (for some reason I erroneously had him with rapiers), so stupidly sold Slicer before reaching Fairloch this time. D'oh. But are you thinking of keeping the pally throughout the second chapter, or just for the Cathedral quest? I ask because if you do intend using him as your tank, you might want to have a word with him about how long he takes to buff before charging in, else you could find yourself wide open. And any further persuasion opportunities yet?

Oh, and just in case you weren't sure, don't bother with riding the horses - it really screws up trap detection, let alone missing some potential conversations. I'm still not sure how they impact on enemies' AC/AB when you face them in combat, but I believe steed and rider still count as one target throughout.

My Junior Hearth Guard's hunting assassins at the moment, with Ronan and Scary Val...

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:
Oh, and just in case you weren't sure, don't bother with riding the horses - it really screws up trap detection, let alone missing some potential conversations. I'm still not sure how they impact on enemies' AC/AB when you face them in combat, but I believe steed and rider still count as one target throughout.
vanilla Horse riding

The Search penalty must be unique onto Aielund scripting.  I've never seen that effected before.

You'll notice a vast disperity of effects from horse riding contributed by different authors and using divergent resources (Aielund uses both CEP and it's own haks as well, hence empowered to make drastic changes) because 5th edition contains the specs, not v3.0.   You'll get a lot of "interpretations" for NWN's version.  There's only one way to learn the nuances (assuming no Readme has been furnished by the author to detail these sorts of things):  Turn on combat debugging mode and note all the information that scrolls by.   I always do that while sampling new content when I know it may not adhere to vanilla rules.

Though only a pally can summon its own mount, all classes can invest in Ride skills (many must xclass, though) and feats.  But both of the prereqs can be further modified via custom scripting.

It will be interesting to read if you guys feel the game has been rebalanced or not (creature skins or AI made more formidable to counter movement boost)  by virtue of the introduction of horse riding.  Typically, its an advantage for pulling apart mobs where the haste property on items and movement buffs are rare or unavailable or just easier to escape pursuit.

posts.author: HipRedux

Stagmeister wrote:
Thanks, Hip, helpful as ever - oh, and did you ever take up playing these mods?

Cheers
Installed but not much doodling yet.  I remember a cleric with a babelicious photo to add to my pin-ups collection and a gnarley fighter guy who seems to have an agenda.  But after doing some odd quests and gathering wolf kills only about level 2 or 3 IIRC.  After committing to taste all the NPC interactions including henchies, I'm wondering how the extended party will affect my leveling rate. Do you guys get around that 35-ish level for the series end when using a full party?  Makes little difference TBH, but I may optimize the build for around that level instead of level 40 (just hate to leave a significant feat left hanging in the air if I can avoid it).

I just need some extended play time to remain focused and "in the spirit" and that particular commodity is elusive these days.  But I do like module so far.  Seems very polished and not subject to many of the oopsies that much of the community-based stuff seems to exhibit (many contributors without English as their native language and it shows).  I've left my adventures in FP's Almraiven on hold along with a handful of other "in process" adventures while delving into this saga.  But I take notes as I go, so as long as I can find them buried among layers of correspondence and print-outs, it's not all that tough picking up where I left off.  Kinda reminds me of the half dozen or so writing projects I'm involved in.  Must be a character flaw, eh?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
The "babelicious" Aasimar to whom you refer would be Nellise - and she's a top girl, if a tad gobby (you'll find out later). And the "gnarly fighter" is Dante, whom you will meet later as well (neither will go to chapter 2 with you, so nick their gear beforehand - they'll both helpfully prompt you to do that anyway).

As to xp: it makes no difference. You gain the points given, solo or in party, which is nice. And have a chat with both these comrades, it's both interesting and gives you prior notice of stuff that may be relevant later on.

For level(l)ing purposes, it might be worth noting that if you decide to take on lots of the Iron Golems at the end of chapter 3 before they reach Highmarch, you can hit level 25 before getting to the final chapter. You are therefore (just about) able to reach level 37 or 38 before the end. It's just about building in a little flexibilty for your final few levels.

Cheers!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: I finished the mod a couple of weeks ago with a chaotic good Sorcerer/Harper scout that focused in evocation, more precisely lightning and cold spells. I went with a party all through the series - first Nellise and Dante, later Valennia and Ronan, and after that Nellise and Robert. My sorc turned out to be an awesome damage dealer, the lightning aoe spells shredding hp's  like mad, wearing them down in no time, and easy pickings for the frontliners. Vs creatures with improved evasion I used Horrid Wilting as a backup, and kept cold spells as backup vs lightning immunes.

I cured the Dwarves of their nasty Duergar infestation. It wasn't easy, but it used to be harder. The throne room used to be full of them, with lots of their wizards. The last hallway to the room with the dragon, who has a name now, also used to be full of them. On the floor above, the dining hall use to have several as well.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:
Sir William did spend a lot of time buffing
 
There is a dialogue option that I have used a lot with Nellise, to ask the henchman to cast buffing spells. You can choose between short time buffs, buffs that last a long time or all buffs. You can also choose who to cast them on. If you ask your hench to cast the long time buffs after resting, the sequence will be shortened when you come to combat. If you know the module and when to expect combat, you can time all buffing to take place before the actual fighting starts.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I have used that many times for Criosa and Nellise, but Sir William doesn't have that dialog option.

EDIT: If he is supposed to have that option, then something has gone wrong. I have already had Criosa pre-buff in Chapter 3 last night.

posts.author: Empyre65

For the first time ever, I was able to talk my way out of fighting Azurefang. I think that only delayed the battle though. Since I didn't kill her, when I get to her lair later, I expect that she will be there.

I have used the dialogue option to avoid that he casts in actual combat, and there is also an option to avoid casting altogether. But I will try to refrain from the latter and see how things evolve.

On a side note; the archer is my Holy Elven Archer, the Paladin 8/wizard 2/AA 30 version, only with the original skill allocation without trap skills. The Holy Elven Archer is kind of a glass cannon with only Con 6 and x-classed tumble. I completed act one solo, but want a party for crowd control now, just to calm the handling down a little. The build really picks up speed now after level 12 when it gets Divine Might.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Today, I have helped the angel in what's-his-name's tomb, the elves in Acadia, and the barbarians, and the only changes I have to report are, as usual, the interiors of the towers, oh, and the ancient white dragon has a name now, as did the black dragon I fought yesterday in the Calespur Ranges.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Iirc, all the boss dragons now have names. Did you end up killing the ancient white one (Hailstorm, I think) or let it go?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I killed it without hesitation. Chromatic dragons are evil, and I needed its horn. In the old version, it was just Ancient White Dragon, and there was no conversation.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Fort Highmarch looks quite different. In addition to the different tileset, the magic shop that is now inside the keep used to be in a small wizard tower next to the church. I can now tell those guys in the pub either my adventure on the Redoubtable or my adventure on the isle of the Dead, when it used to be always the Redoubtable story.

The area south of Highmarch is also quite different from before, but the next area, north of Trinity is unchanged. The area south if Trinity before you reach the sandstorm is different, but the sandstorm area is the same. Trinity itself is changed very little, with fancy opening curtains in some doorways that weren't there before. The area west of Trinity has been changed, too, but I think it is still the same tileset with a new layout. I have the game saved right after I hired Azurefang to help fight the Ironlord, something that I never knew was an option. It might or might have been possible before, but I always have had to fight her the first time I encounter her. I will enter the ancient dungeon next time,

posts.author: Empyre65

I forgot to mention that in the pub, I passed every check and they were enraptured by my tale the whole way though. I've won the bet before, but never that completely.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I just finished chapter 3, and the battle is very different. Before, there was no placing of troops, and no siege golem. The enemy would break through the door and we would fight them. Once we were overwhelmed, we would retreat into the keep and talk to the king, The Iron Lord would enter and parley, and then start fighting with us when we didn't surrender (which wasn't a dialog option). After a short while of seemingly hopeless fighting, Terinus would appear and give me the scepter, and I would use it, and then we could win the fight.

Oh, and the ancient dungeon where we get the final piece of the scepter was unchanged.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote:
 On a side note; the archer is my Holy Elven Archer, the Paladin 8/wizard 2/AA 30 version, only with the original skill allocation without trap skills. The Holy Elven Archer is kind of a glass cannon with only Con 6 and x-classed tumble. At level 1 it only has 2 hitpoints! But the build is fun to play if you are very careful during the early levels. I completed act one solo, but want a party for crowd control now, just to calm the handling down a little. The build really picks up speed now after level 12 when it gets Divine Might.
I've been running my elven Monk11/Wiz2/AA27 through Aielund (haven't found her a suitable build name yet) - and running is definitely the operative word. The final battle of Part 1 was particularly interesting. Unfortunately, I was the only one left standing by the end of it (bar Criosa, who I'd parked up near where we first came in). Nell took an unlucky early sneak/crit and went down, and Dante did his best as meat shield, but followed her into the abyss not long afterwards. This left me, Robert Black, 9 Steel Tigers and one remaining spy (I'd concentrated my early fire on taking down the sorcerer). The gun-and-run approach proved very effective, even outpacing the mounted Mr Black, who was the last to die. It took a long time, so I missed out on some of the loot, but was well worth it for the practice in a different playing style. And I was able to raise Nell and Dante, which assuaged some of my guilt at their demises. I now begin to see how soloing Part 1 could work.

I'm now in Part 2, at level 11, with Ronan and Sir William. We've done the University, Cathedral, Admiralty and Library, and I'm now wondering whether to drop the pally for Valennia before dealing with the docks and heading into the sewers. Both have their plusses and minuses. I'm also using the Daiyku+3 longbow and the bracers of archery (which grant WS in longbow), which together with only 2 levels of AA, have considerably boosted my strike/damage rate.

It's all a very different experience from playing Wulgar - the only other archer build I've attempted. Not better or worse, just different...

posts.author: Empyre65

It took 3 tries, but I was able to talk my way out of that desert battle against Aielunders.

The fight with the ice elemental in the sewers was really hard this time. On the 6th or 7th try, I had to flee to the church for healing a few times and use 3 Raise dead scrolls, but I finally defeated them all. Once again, I think it was because I was an archer forced to use a melee weapon, like with that statue. I got nice bracers as a reward that will help me a lot as a archer. That's as far as I got last night.

I made it to Trinity, and everything I saw today looks unchanged.

I also got 10000 experience points.

In the battle in Lowmarch, Cadmus the uber vampire died, and I thought aloud, like I do, "Oh no! That's not a favorable outcome!" It turns out that it was favorable after all. It didn't affect my experience points, and I got a really really nice sword off of him. It is +5 and does 1d6 each of 3 different types of elemental damage. That is even better than Lightbringer, which Nelise had before.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I assumed that anything left in their inventories would be lost like in earlier chapters, so I put everything in my own inventory.

I just finished the Aielund Saga. Almost nothing is changed in the final chapter. The Tempest look different. It used to look more human-shaped, like a golem or earth elemental, but made of dark clouds with lightning. After you answer the first riddle, in addition to those super-nice monk gloves, the dragon offers a bow that is even better than Zen. Later, she offers a Monk robe, but I can tell you that 35 UMD is not enough to be able to use it.

After so many battles being unusually tough, presumably because I am an archer, the battle with Abaddon went really well. We won on the first try. The battle with the Dreadnoughts was a little bit tougher, but not too bad. The battle with the commander, who didn't used to have that armor, nor did he used to summon that big spider thing, was brutal. To win, I had to continuously feed heal and epic heal potions to the other party members like they were water. It's a good thing that I had hoarded so many. I didn't get to do much fighting myself. Despite my efforts, I still had to resurrect Robert once during the attempt in which we finally won.

An interesting note: I reached level 37 while battling to activate the second switch to open the door to the command center.

Next, I plan to play the Adam Miller campaign as a Fighter 8 / Bard 4 / RDD 8, except I won't reach level 20. This isn't the thread to discuss my progress in that campaign, but there is a thread for that. I might get sidetracked mapping and modding for Doom for a while before I start, though.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Many thanks for cataloging all the differences, Empyre - greatly appreciated!

As a side note, I can confirm that both Robert and Nell will hold onto any items you place into their inventories prior to teleporting to Terry's tower.

I picked up the Eldar Bow you mention - nice! What I've done is have Terry enhance Zen to +10 and have that as my unlimited +5 arrows chucker, while saving my "best" bow for specialized arrows (like the Divine ones from Assumption and the magic damage ones from the mercs). I also got the monk robes (being a Monk AA UMD wasn't an issue), which I'll give details of once I've found where I've written them down. I've also taken on board your tip of hoarding the epic heal potions rather than divvying them up early and have the others fritter them away. Oh, and I'm now Mrs Black! Blimey - you kill a man and this is where it gets you...

Am about to go confront Abaddon now, at level 35 and sitting on an AC of 71, with an AB of +66 etc. It would have been better, xp-wise, if I'd managed to save any of the Tusone archers earlier on, but I sadly failed in that. I decided to bite the bullet rather than reload, figuring I could make up the loss during the Battle of Fairloch - no other ranged competition. I reckon I should still hit level 37 before the end.

I'm gathering the impression that persuasive is a fine path to follow - you seem to have garnered more from it than you lost. Thanks again for all the info

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
The Monk robes from Xrnamaxus are Adamantium Robes of Harmony - normal robe stats with +7 Armour modifier, DR+7 soak 20, WIS+4. Haste and Freedom, with Epic Spell Warding 1xp/day.

Just stopped the weapon from firing with under 30 seconds to go...

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: That reminds me. In the old version, you had five minutes to stop the weapon, but now you have seven minutes. That's much easier. I definitely like that change.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Just a couple of idle musings, if I may. Some of you may recall I had a problem with a Dwarven Defender and the dragon, Scar, in Part 3, just south of Trinity, in that my PC wouldn't attack. I believe the consensus was that it was a problem with Defensive Stance. But it ain't. I'm currently barrelling through with Valerfor's Iron Fist Monk (Monk 35 / Fighter 5), and the same thing happened again. It would appear that while Scar is perfectly prepared to stomp on those of a Dwarven ilk, he's not prepared to suffer the indignity of an attack from one of them. I solved it this time by Benny Hill-ing him, leaving Robert Black to knock him into a week on Wednesday (for those not knowing Benny's work, his TV shows invariably ended with him running around at top speed being chased by a gaggle of comely wenches). This has only happened when I've played a Dwarf - anyone else had the same?

Secondly, the sword Stormbringer. I haven't paid proper attention to the inscription on its hilt before, but now I find myself wondering: is it a tribute to Michael Moorcock's Elric of Melnibone and his sword of the same name (twinned with Mournblade, if I recall)? Or to Deep Purple's album/song of that name - or indeed Ritchie Blackmore's Rainbow? If anyone knows, I'd be interested...

As I said, musings.

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I had a look, too, Aquarius, and as it warns, it is indeed out of date in some things, but nevertheless very handy.

One of the things it doesn't mention is the impact a friendly yet vexed badger can have (now there's a sentence I never thought I'd type). I'm currently taking Ren from MTS - courtesy of Valerfor's adaptations - for a trip through Aielund, and I reckon I'm about 6-700 xp down on the deal, thanks to a badger who got in the killing blow for both the Elite Poacher and his dog in the rangers' area. It both made me smile and annoyed me - I'm now levelling up just that little bit later, which of course matters not a jot later on, but in early levels does rather.

Anyway, have just entered the caves looking for an errant princess (alas, without hard-ass badger in tow) at level 8.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Am currently in Fairloch in Chapter 2, and have decided to take Maggie, the halfling Druid, with me (having taken Sir William for the Cathedral Quest, then parked the Pally back in the Fair Maiden Tavern). This is for two reasons: first, I thought Valennia would be over-egging the greatsword-wielding warrior-woman pudding a touch, what with Ren being one as well; and second, I wanted to see how she performed while having only one proper front-liner in the party (me).

Now, I'm not sure whether this is Aielund-specific or applies more broadly, but Maggie will not use a sling with a shield equiped (she's fine with a dagger). Is that because I have her with a large shield, and she'd be ok with a buckler/small shield? Or is it just the way it is?

Also, and I'm hoping it's just a hiccup, I don't seem able to access her feats and skills when examining her character info atm.

And just to clarify, Maggie's "quest" is to rid the Amalis region of shadow druids, which we'll be doing anyway erelong.

Any help with the shield thing would be appreciated, thanks.

EDIT: It's got weirder. Maggie will now equip her shield without prompting as soon as she casts Stoneskin, and then seems happy to carry it until we rest, when we have to go through the whole malarkey again. Oh, and the hiccup was just that.

EDIT 2: Well, it's clearly not a generic problem with Maggie. We're now on the way to Amarillo - sorry, Amalis (even though the song's now fixed in my head) - and she's using a large shield when she feels like it, so I've given up trying to understand her. I did have to have a word about her squandering her spells: Ice Storm and Lightning Strike for two orc archers seemed a tad extreme...

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content: Me and my merry band during Act 2 on my very first, chaotic evil playthrough, glamour shot.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: It is even possible to complete the campaign playing as evil?

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote: It is even possible to complete the campaign playing as evil?
Oh, yes that is not only possible - it opens up new opportunities

First of all - there is no alignment restrictions on your PC, and all "evil classes" are in.
There are dialogue options when completing quests, and during several other dialogues, that let you omit most alignment adjustments to good, and there are also several evil options from time to time.
And the story still makes sense: Evil people want to take part in the story, but with a different motivation. Save the world any day, not for the benefit of all, but to further yourself and grab the opportunities you create for yourself, no matter if it causes others to suffer. And if you remove other villains, that only opens up new doors for yourself.

Evil spoiler:
Spoiler If you don't mind the alignment shift towards evil - and you don't - you are now free to slay commoners, and city guards for xp and items to sell. And it doesn't break anything plot-wise as long as you don't remove guards that are there to open doors/gates for you to advance quests. They turn hostile when you attack, but their perception range is limited, so only the ones closest to the one you attack "turn red". And after a couple of minutes they turn non-hostile again if you run and escape. Then you can talk to them again, like nothing happened. They must have very bad memory. A warning though: The empty streets, inns and bars feel very empty and spooky when you have killed everybody...

posts.content:

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
Well, we'll see if I can finish it, I'm at the point where the screenshot was taken - midway around Act 2.
I wanted to (mostly) solo, thus a character whose idea of teamwork is dressing up his companions and leaving them at the palace entrance to let all passer-by's know that they are on HIS team made sense. The character already thinks of the castle as his castle. He's jovial, cynical, friendly, abusive, selfish. He thinks of himself as an artist first and foremost. He does "other business too, to make ends meet", he says. In reality, most of his efforts are spent on powermongering and he's thrilled when he had official executive power to ransack ("investigate") the houses of two very powerful families in town. He keeps incriminating evidence in several binders, arranged alphabetically.
At the beginning of Act 2, when you are supposed to escort Criosa to the castle straight away but she'd rather go shopping, Klingsor immediately stepped up to the task and told Her Majesty that shopping was one of his favourite pastimes as well, and he would be overjoyed to be given the opportunity to fulfil her such wishes. After all they've been through (read, Klingsor cut down the enemy and went back to the entrance to pick Criosa back up in Act 1) this was the least he could do. We got Criosa a very smart dress.

EDIT: Regarding quests, I've been reading Lilura's walkthrough post-game. Every time I pass an area, I read up on her experiences, and she was playing a paladin. There are quests and a companion I don't get because I'm evil and non-LG, respectively, and the Church hates my guts. I get really well on with soldiers.
In dialogue, I find I often choose the Chaotic and Good options, a lot of times when I try to schmooze up to aristocracy, and of course the game has no way of knowing if my character actually means what he says or in what tone he'd say it, so many times my alignment nudges towards Good. I sometimes have to commit random acts of what the game perceives as evil to compensate for acts the game perceived as good. This would be a good opportunity to RP alignment shift, but first of all, I'm part BG so I must stay evil for gameplay purposes, and second of all I want to explore thinking with a mind of a friendly monster who's antisocial (since he's selfish and self-focused) but has very good social skills.

Hi Mirnaia - forgot to say hello last time, sorry! Don't know what else you've got in the build other than BG, but if you've got any Bard in there you can grab a micro-quest in the theatre in Fairloch's market district - if not, you can't.

Personally, I think the henchies in Aielund are really good value and add to the overall experience - decent banter, but not too much, and a damn sight better AI than elsewhere, as well as the PC being better able to request what they want from them. Every one of them has a distinct and realistic personality - and you'll still end up at level 36/7 with or without them.

Besides, Valennia Far Eagle in a frock is just wrong

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Not only do I think you're right, but I recall now that it was after I solved the monks' problem in the caves.

I have noticed quite a few minor changes, but some of them might have already been in place the one-and-only time I played the previous version that you're familiar with.

The timer for resting is now 3 in-game hours (6 minutes).

Ride-able horses are gone, but some NPCs still ride them. Oddly, the dialog option is still there to tell henchmen to get off their horse.

You finally get experience points for killing the cunning wolf that had been attacking the cattle in Bracksford.

When you put the weapon back into the casket on the Isle of the Dead, the mummy no longer spawns again.

When I met Spartan, I asked him to join me, assuming that he wouldn't because my party was full, but he joined as a 3rd henchman! He almost died fighting those nearby giants, reminding me why I don't usually want him in my party.

It might have been a glitch, but Nelise was nowhere to be found in Culdeny in Chapter 3.

... and other little things.

With Bard taking an extra 2 skill points in Aielund, the build gets a further 16 points, and I'm thinking of sticking them into Concentration to try and resist that early nasty taunting from the barbarians, rather than boosting Spellcraft or Lore.

Putting those points in Lore would be less useless, or maybe a few of them in Appraise, like at levels 7 and 12.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
@ Empyre: Aye, you're right about Concentration, but just to be a contrary little bugger, I'm popping some in Persuade (atm, despite having 0 points in it to date, I'm hitting persuades I haven't before, so why not help luck along a bit, eh?).

Anyway, the point of this post is to ask you, as our pioneer in the "new" Aielund, whether you reckon it might let you reach beyond level 36? I know I've been to 37 before, but it tends to be whilst just before facing the final foe. Still, no bad thing, but it would be lovely to think it now takes you all the way. Please keep us posted!

posts.author: jiameepok
posts.content:
Hi, I am looking to start my first play through in Aielund Saga.
Wanted to try out this Melee Mage build instead of a usual fighter tank:
melee-mage-wizard-40-t2354625.html

Is this build viable or is Aielund Saga too high magic for it be effective ?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
jiameepok wrote: Hi, I am looking to start my first play through in Aielund Saga.
Wanted to try out this Melee Mage build instead of a usual fighter tank:
melee-mage-wizard-40-t2354625.html

Is this build viable or is Aielund Saga too high magic for it be effective ?
After the first chapter, Aielund starts to become pretty high magic. Also, there is a resting restriction: you have to wait 3 in-game hours before resting again (6 real-life minutes).

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Melee mage is a philosophy rather than a build, it, of course, can complete successfully Aielund but you will be better served by using an actual spellsword with more attacks/round and stronger AB.

posts.author: rangersg
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote:
wildleaf wrote: Can Aielund be played multiplayer, with friends? I tried it out for like 20 minutes with a friend and it didn't seem to work right.
I think Stag has done that.
I have played the 2 first parts multiplayer with a DM. That was several years ago, so I don't know how the later updates work in MP.
I've played through the end of Part 3 multiplayer with no problem. I have not tried Part IV multi to see how the whole beginning of the Act would play out. But worst case, you can do as Baldecaren recommends with Prophet and its prologue, play that part with 1 person (logical choice is if someone did the Criosa arc), and then join in with the other PCs in the Desert. RP it as helping the escape. From there, I think you'd be fine.

posts.author: rangersg
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: Melee mage is a philosophy rather than a build, it, of course, can complete successfully Aielund but you will be better served by using an actual spellsword with more attacks/round and stronger AB.
And this is what I'm wanting to try to build. A quality spellsword, viable throughout the Saga (because I refuse to be carried by my companions) that isn't another Paladin/Sorcerer. I can make a good arcane trickster. But that's Criosa. And yes, I could do it better. But I can't bring myself to sit the Princess.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: I'm not a user of the arcane arts, but conceptually, would something like a Fighter/CoT/Bard or Sorcerer make any sense? Possibly Ranger for Fighter if you fancy DEX-ing and Dual-Wielding. Just spit-balling, here...

posts.author: rangersg
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: I'm not a user of the arcane arts, but conceptually, would something like a Fighter/CoT/Bard or Sorcerer make any sense? Possibly Ranger for Fighter if you fancy DEX-ing and Dual-Wielding. Just spit-balling, here...
Well, bard isn't really my idea of a spellsword. More the arcane trickster. Sorcerer would work w/ Blackguard if I wanted to be THAT guy. But why Fighter/CoT when Paladin gives me better saves, the Divine Feats of CoT, and does so taking up fewer spellcasting levels? Ranger/Wizard can be fun (sorcerer less so, because there are too many stats required to make it work). But I typically end in something w/ AA. And I just played an Arcane Archer a few months back, before I knew this version came out. 

Ranger/Wizard/CoT is not terrible. But other than minor save boosts, I'm not sure what CoT gives me there, given that again to make the build work, I have to dump CHA, so the Divine Feats are pointless. (Let alone I hate dropping XP in Aielund because of failed persuades. I've already done it too many times with this Wizard.) If I were doing this, I'd probably drop SD on top, take the 5 levels for ED, and choose Undead, Constructs, and Outsiders as my FE. That's 10 lvls of Ranger, 5 of SD, 22 levels of Wizard, (assuming lvl 37, which is where I typically max at). Less than 9 of Ranger makes no sense anyway because I'd want the IDW, so might as well take 10 and get the 3rd FE, which is entirely justified for RP anyway. Hmmm. It's not terrible. But I think I'm giving up way too much spellpower for the joy of 2 weapons. 

OTOH, with the Black One as the primary nuker, I could go straight buffs, summons, and no-saves. For all the AI nastiness in Aielund, the number of times I've actually seen Mords thrown is fairly small. (The Tower w/ Veronica, the Black One himself before that, and the final battle...once I think?) Might work. I'd either be light on heals or tanking in Act 3. But nothing I didn't do before w/ a Wizard, Criosa, and RB.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
The CoT I was wondering about was for BFs and saves primarily - I've never really got on that well with smiting. And as a predominantly melee player, I really, really hate Will fails.

It's a different sort of focus, but have you run with Nell in Part 3? I did for my first few trips into Aielund (mostly because I was mismanaging Bobby), and she's well worth it. At that time she has a couple of Pally levels, with the rest in Cleric. So buffs are very well catered for, and you can concentrate fully on either tanking or full-on front-line activities. That said, I recognise your desire not to be over reliant on henchies.

At least it's got you mulling!

Yeah, the save boost would be non-trivial. Not sure it would be enough to avoid total stun lock in the end. Though there is always mind blank. 

And oh yes, I've partied with Nell many, many times. :P Buffed she's a more than serviceable tank. Especially if you choose a certain sword for a tomb reward. OTOH, EMS nerfs the duration of a host of buffs substantially across the board, and cleric more than wizard, IIRC. And watching for those to drop is harder on henchies than me. That said, the rest timer is now down to an almost "Why" level in the newest version. (6 minutes) I have yet to clear a level and have to wait out the timer, as I did in the caves of part 1 when you'd slog past Umber Hulks, Hook Horrors, and Dire Spiders to be rewarded with wyverns. :P Which is fine with me, I vehemently disagree with rest timers. It's not like fighters don't outstrip wizards for damage output already.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I have soloed the whole campaign on D&D hardcore rules. I have made it a habit to play on that difficulty setting.

The damage rolls against you are doubled when you choose "Very Difficult". Everything else is equal on D&D hardcore.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Going with the henchmen makes the story richer.
I just wanted to see if it could be done without them. And I like playing rogue types.
HIPS, once you get that, makes crowd control much easier, except against true-seers. CoT adds the 4th attack, better saves,  more feats and Shield proficiency so you can sword'n board if you need high AC.
I can post the build. But figuring out how to beat the game in different scenarios, is what becomes the biggest challenge. And I enjoy doing that with rogues.

Edit: As for Terry...
Spoiler He showed up in the final act. I spoke with him to get the instructions that move the plot forward. Then went alone and destroyed the powerplant and crystals to stop the count down. After that I had plenty of time to clean up everything.  Finally I rejoined Terry and took him to the control bridge where he could finish the quest.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Earlier in this thread the subject of Maggie (the halfling druid henchie in chapter 2) came up. I've been travelling with her in my current run-through with Empyre's Katana Master (Fighter 10/ Bard 8/ WM 22), and she's awesome. Her AI even compensates for my own inadequacies - like if I forget to sing a tune before a battle she'll barkskin me and otherwise buff me without asking, which is nice. She only casts firestorms and lightning strikes against frost giants, saving her icestorms for other foes. I've equipped her with the Hide of the Grizzly for a boost to strength when in melee (for which her massive dagger is fine), otherwise the elite druid armour.

She also has some cracking lines. My two favourites atm are: "Aww, you afraid of a little halfling lass? You should be." and, after defeating the frost giants, "Another victory for the small over the big. Yay me!"

One thing, though, when you first enter the shadow druid enclave, and if your persuade skills aren't high enough, she will be recognised and the slug-fest begins.

Just thought I'd give a quick update on a very worthwhile companion.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I seriously can't tell you how good Maggie was on the Isle of the Dead. Absolutely stunning. I know in this shot she's gone all elemental, but still, she just keeps getting better.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: And that's the whole idiocy - why give an NPC feats the PC then has to tell them not to use?
Part of the reason the NPC's have a number of odd feat choices are the pre-leveling packages. Basically, when creating an NPC in the toolset there are some pre-leveling packages that assign specific feats based on the level of the character and the package choice. So, if a package had a cool name like "dual-wielder kensai" or something similar and the creator of the module thought "that sounds perfect for this guy", then an automatic choice was made and the character got all those feats.

I do not know for sure that this is exactly what happened here, but that would be my rough estimation based on other NPC's I have seen in the past.
