Here is the build:
Spoiler Monk(11), Illusionist(2), Arcane Archer(27), Elf STR: 14 CON: 10 INT: 14 01: Monk(1): Point Blank Shot, {Cleave, Evasion, Improved Unarmed Strike, Stunning Fist} 03: Monk(3): Rapid Shot 05: Monk(5) 07: Monk(7) 09: Illusionist(2): Blind Fight 11: Arcane Archer(2) 13: Arcane Archer(4) 15: Arcane Archer(6): Improved Critical: Longbow 17: Monk(8) 19: Arcane Archer(9) 21: Arcane Archer(11): Epic Weapon Focus: Longbow 23: Arcane Archer(12) 25: Arcane Archer(14): Epic Prowess 27: Monk(10): Great Dexterity I, (DEX=25) 29: Arcane Archer(17) 31: Arcane Archer(19) 33: Arcane Archer(21): Great Dexterity IV, (DEX=30) 35: Arcane Archer(23) 37: Monk(11) 39: Arcane Archer(26): Great Dexterity VII, Great Dexterity VIII, (DEX=35) Skillpoints: 254 Saving Throw bonuses: Mind Effects: +4 AB (max, naked): 41 (melee), 58 (ranged) Spell Casting: Wizard(1)
It has much in common with your monk archer.
If I should play her again, I would have changed the pre-epic feat order and taken Weapon Finesse at level 9 or 12 and moved Called Shot to 18.
SpoilerI would probably also maxed Listen at the expense of maxing out Spot after you get True Seeing late in the game.
When I say that I soloed, well...
Spoiler I talked to the Barbarian chief upon entering the caves and went back to take him to the HQ after finishing everybody. I did take Mr Paladin to church for his quest, but left him upstairs to wait until I had finished it. This earned me some xp. I let Nellise meet her father, but did not involve her in any of the combat in Hell. That was worth some xp and a cool happening. I let Terry do his thing to destroy the saqaarin base after I had cleared it. It was not possible to avoid mass combat with NPCs taking part In the battle at Highmarch against the Ironlord. But I was able to defeat all the constructs that spawned at the hillside south of it. The rangers there only put up a minor resistance, so it was almost solo. There was also a skirmish outside of Trinity when I first met the king.
I used run'n gun tactics a lot. Rapid shot was almost always active. But I also used other tactics. Especially in pre-epic levels I also used traps, and even killed some bosses with stacked traps. I did some melee fighting as a back up plan, both with Gloves and Kama. An earlier Weapon Finesse would have helped, but in the pre-epic game the difference was not as bad as one might think when I put on my strength gear and swallowed a Bull's potion.
I was able to get a high AC throughout the game, and seldom missed Discipline. I often had success with point-blank shooting, as long as I could use choke points to avoid being surrounded. The Called Shot routine to slow down single attackers was one thing I used very little. That was simply because of the speed my character had, and the other options with traps and close combat.

As for equipment:
Spoiler There are some very good bows in the game. They scale well with the item level in general. Monk items and caster items are plentiful and very good, so I seldom missed UMD. There are bracers that improve ranged combat with WF, WS, EWF and EWS for both Shortbow and Longbow. So I never missed those Fighter levels.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
After abandoning my previous playthrough (you can find it a few pages back), I started a new, LG, team one. It's a not very original F/R/WM7, Dex-based rapier-wielder build, because I wanted to have enough points for the three social skills. She's called Roxanne, I have a screenshot of her socketing a red light gem, but I'm typing this from a playground on my phone, so that'll have to wait.

EMS is disabled because the documentation is more like a steam-of-consciousness of nerdrage than a documentation and that put me off.

I'm currently at the beginning of Act III, just finished re-exploring Fairloch and shopping. I only discovered at the end of the previous act that you can have more than two companions in your party, so I probably missed out on a bit of banter, as I only had Maggie and Ronan with me throughout. I can see how the Roebec-Black-Sanneman trio is going to be hilarious to adventure with. Also, buffalicious.

Writing as someone who has never finished the saga, gameplay so far is very very solid. The module is full of great ideas, great design and implementation, and sub-par dialogue. To put that last point into perspective, I keep catching myself thinking dragon age/mass effect did it better, so after all it's not too bad if the writing fails to live up to some of the best RPGs ever produced commercially. The author, however, has zero grasp on it's v its (it's consistently it's). I know it's something native speakers tend to have MORE trouble with than non-natives like myself. However, these are small gripes. The effort behind the game is unbelievable. It gets so many things right.

As much as I'm a rogue at heart when it comes to CRPG's, NWN is the one game where if I'm not playing a caster, I tend to feel as helpless as a newborn :) In Aielund, companion buffs + UMD do help. The bracers I bought in Amalis in Act 2 are a godsend, with GMW (15), Stoneskin, and even Spell Mantle in a pinch. Oh, and +2 Dex. They're "only usable by Sorcerer", but they are a UMD rogue's wet dream at the point you get it.
The armour I got from rescuing the linguist is still the only permahaste item I have. It really shows how useful the property is - I'm using it even tough I could already get +3/+4 AC from UMD monk robes (depending on Criosa's Cat's roll). I respect modules that don't throw permahaste in your way with a high hand.

It does seem like you can have at least 4 party members. I have now reached Culdeny and have a fourth companion (the metalhead). I also believe that so far whatever could be solved diplomatically has been solved diplomatically, including the frost giants and The Pass.
Controlling a party in a game very much not designed for it is difficult, even with the shortcut commands. Mostly because in this game, first strike means so much*. In the Undercity I found myself having an easier time stocking my companions at the stairway and scouting and fighting ahead on my own. This way my friends did not set off traps I was in the middle of disarming and did not wander off in 3 directions at once, pulling every enemy on the map. I did call them for the boss, they got stuck in the doorway while I did the fighting :) (I do have the party move tool hotkeyed, but it was not an overly difficult fight)

Going to sleep just before doing some plumbing in Culdeny.

*Example: attacking a wizard with high level spells and you have more than 3 attacks per round. If you get first strike, for all intents and purposes you have a 399/400 chance of knocking the wizard down, and you win. If the wizard gets first strike, it's time stop / mord's / time stop / GS / buff time, and that's really not what you want.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
https://neverwintervault.org/tags/aielund-saga
Download the modules (it's a trilogy in four parts of six modules! (actually, seven)), paying attention to the extra files and where they go.

After action report: I have reached the first decision that looks like it will actually impact what is to come. I'm talking about below Fort Highmarch. It made me stop and think, and I love that. I took the conservative option, not wishing to turn the world as people know it upside down just before a major battle, and because I'm more concerned about being able to do something the act's title character than playing Truman Show with the fort's commander. I did save before the decision, and I'll check out later how the other path plays out.

The road back to Highmarch definitely had its moments of brilliance. First of all, the idea of doing your Act 1+2 trek backwards is fantastic. Seeing how the world changes is one of my favourite things in rpg's and Aielund very much hits the nail on the head here. The trading company quest (very "Biowareish" in philosophy) in Culdeny was hilariously entertaining. This is how you do a FedEx quest without boring the player.

The elves have a lot of extra reactions if Spartan is in your party (they know him(?)). Again, the dialogue writing is a bit college-y at certain points, but the module has such huge momentum that I didn't really mind. Come to think of Spartan, he didn't fully grasp the idea that people generally keep dogs, not wolves, as pets.

Never having played a Fighter/Rogue/WM7 before, I'm very happy with the build. I know it's a classic, and even though I had to sacrifice skills to get bluff/intimidate/persuade (and thus I went with Dex 18 Int 16 Str 12 and three 8's), it still rocks, very dodge-and-weavey playstyle, very strong in melee. It's also going to be my first character with ED (but it will come late in the module). I always thought it's not that much to dodge a single attack against a single opponent per round, and I wonder why it's the holy grail of Dex builds, but I hope my opinion will change when I see it in action.

Time to go and save the day. Although a quick glance at Act IV's title tells me that's not going to happen.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
@ Mirnaia,

The thing with dextrous types is that they have "the whole package" and not only ED. You see, every decent dextrous warrior will have at least a plus 6 (or more) AC than a similar FP type warrior so he/she will be much harder to get hit, now add ED on top of that and that's where the magic happens...

A build like Max's "Drow fencer" with its 36 natural dexterity will have exactly 10 more AC than a FP warrior (with full tumble skill) and ED on top of that to shrug-off that one lucky "natural twenty" of the enemy so it might -at times- seem "invulnerable" even, except for magic attacks...

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Mirnaia wrote:https://neverwintervault.org/tags/aielund-saga
Download the modules (it's a trilogy in four parts of six modules! (actually, seven)), paying attention to the extra files and where they go.

After action report: I have reached the first decision that looks like it will actually impact what is to come. I'm talking about below Fort Highmarch. It made me stop and think, and I love that. I took the conservative option, not wishing to turn the world as people know it upside down just before a major battle, and because I'm more concerned about being able to do something the act's title character than playing Truman Show with the fort's commander. I did save before the decision, and I'll check out later how the other path plays out.

The road back to Highmarch definitely had its moments of brilliance. First of all, the idea of doing your Act 1+2 trek backwards is fantastic. Seeing how the world changes is one of my favourite things in rpg's and Aielund very much hits the nail on the head here. The trading company quest (very "Biowareish" in philosophy) in Culdeny was hilariously entertaining. This is how you do a FedEx quest without boring the player.

The elves have a lot of extra reactions if Spartan is in your party (they know him(?)). Again, the dialogue writing is a bit college-y at certain points, but the module has such huge momentum that I didn't really mind. Come to think of Spartan, he didn't fully grasp the idea that people generally keep dogs, not wolves, as pets.

Never having played a Fighter/Rogue/WM7 before, I'm very happy with the build. I know it's a classic, and even though I had to sacrifice skills to get bluff/intimidate/persuade (and thus I went with Dex 18 Int 16 Str 12 and three 8's), it still rocks, very dodge-and-weavey playstyle, very strong in melee. It's also going to be my first character with ED (but it will come late in the module). I always thought it's not that much to dodge a single attack against a single opponent per round, and I wonder why it's the holy grail of Dex builds, but I hope my opinion will change when I see it in action.

Time to go and save the day. Although a quick glance at Act IV's title tells me that's not going to happen.
Hey dude! Is it the Drow Fencer you're rocking around?


Sent from my iPad using Tapatalk

posts.author: Mirnaia

Maximillian_Kane wrote:
Hey dude! Is it the Drow Fencer you're rocking around?
Basically yes! I was looking at the drow fencer when plotting the build in CBC. It's a human to avoid any XP penalty for a non-respawning world and the extra feat and skill points, Con 8 and Int 16 for even more skill points, and I still had to compromise. It's a very good fencer and sneaker. Rogues have many skill points, but even more useful skill, and I wanted to take 3 normally "useless" ones.

eltalstro wrote: Just started act 3. Seems like the difficulty steps up a bit against the duergar. Hats off to anyone who has solo navigated this module; it's getting tough.
For the duergar in Undercity, it's great for a commando style approach (it's easier solo than with a team). I parked the party at the staircase, buffed up via Nellise and then Criosa, and snuck around, disarming traps and knocking wizards over the head. The layout really lends itself for (to?) this, plenty of corners to duck behind. "Rogues do it from behind", but really, never fight fair should be every character's motto.


Just after I wrote about the decision below Highmarch, the quest decided to be a bit buggy, and
Spoilerif you recall, I initially wanted to side with Arminus. When I typed that previous comment, I have just killed So, in the end, Saffron and the Baron moved downstairs to have a population 0 underground kingdom all for themselves! P.s. I can only hope that they will alternate in wearing the solar protection ring.
Two more quests that were somewhat bugged:
Spoiler Back in Act II, at the beginning, the quest for telling the captain about the ship following the Redoubtable never concluded in the quest log. And in Act III, the evacuation of Bracksford never concluded. Tom Bollard (I believe he's the barkeep?) decided to stay in the barracks for some reason as everyone else marched out of the rax and out of town (they were nowhere to be found on the map between Bracksford and Culdeny), so I have no idea how that quest would have finished. I wouldn't mind an explicit spolier, since I'm quite a bit past that part.
I reached Trinity, did everything there was to do there on my first visit (the Tusonite ambassador's wife has MY portrait, oh, the cheek!), and went west first of the two possibilities of where to continute.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
That's interesting about your first spoiler, Mirnaia...
SpoilerI've only ever sided with Catharch, and never had a problem subsequently - though I am still intrigued by that unopenable safe halfway between them. I have no idea what resides in there. I don't know what will happen when you return to Highmarch from Trinity with the pieces of the sceptre, but Catharch always came out to assist in the humongous battle at the end of Act III.
In respect of your second spoiler:
SpoilerI'm assuming you did report back to the captain about the following ship in Act II. That's always completed the quest for me. Equally, I've never had anyone remain behind in the barracks in Bracksworth. Normally, once you escort them out of the barracks, they all just leg it for Culdeny, and you won't see them again until Act IV (but at least you'll then know they made it, even if they're in trouble again) - and you won't see the sage behind the lightning barrier again at all.
I just wonder which version you're playing? One of the newly updated ones might have a few previously unknown glitches.

EDIT: And you appear to have taken the tougher option from Trinity first. Better xp, but can get nasty. I doubt you'll have anything with positive energy protection, but if you do, wear it - particularly on the bottom level and when leaving. Oh, and when heading south from Trinity, you might want some fire protection on you for the first screen.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
First of all, I still play on Hardcore DnD difficulty, not the Very difficult setting! The difference is that damage is doubled on Very difficult.
Spoiler I had the best AC gear I could get at that stage, including a Tower shield. I can't remember if I had any DR gear, but I probably had some. I also equipped my character with a Ring of Regeneration to slow down the withering. The build has several active combat moves and I used Expertise a lot when surrounded.
What is important in that area is how you handle crowd control (and party control )
The Epic Brawler Champion build is made to wade into the fray and shrug off most of what is thrown at it; taunts, blows, magic, traps etc. You have several combat moves that you can switch between.
I had to use a completely different approach with the Rogue/ CoT/ SD, when I soloed that character, a dex based elf with Con 10. With that character I used stealth, HIPS and traps for crowd control.
With my Monk/Wizard/AA which is a Run'n gunner, I had nowhere to run. I had a hard time trying to single out each creature. And when that didn't work, I used "choke point" tactics as much as possible to avoid being completely swarmed. In the worst cases I had to resort to regular melee to avoid being hammered by attacks of opportunity.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
Woah… this module is fantastic. I had very little time to play last week, where I finished Act 3, and two days ago, in a marathon session of 11 AM to 4 AM the next day (oopsie), I went from the beginning of Act 4 through the Hall of Very Long to the Castle of Many Riddles.

Not wanting to put basically the entire post inside a spoiler tag, you have been warned that there are ***SPOILERS*** to follow, which, in all honesty, shouldn't be too surprising in such a thread :)

The rest of the actions leading up to the end of Act 3 were nothing to write home about, the positive energy bit was mostly harmless (everybody had some regen and fear protection throughout the act). In the tower where you fight your first legionnaire, there were two circular rooms shown on the map that I couldn't access, below two other circular rooms and next to the one where you have said fight (and have pretty good Search).

I was left with a few open questions upon returning to Trinity. Am I correct that you can't do anything about the Ironlord there? I just had to tank him while killing the rest of his merry little band he appeared alongside. And I assume it's also intended that when you retreat to the North he doesn't follow you. Let me know if there is something I missed.

I walked back to Highmarch, and encountered the Rangers in the long snowy map south of it, but that bit never saw any action during the battle - did I screw something up? I took a peak at the place during the battle of Highmarch, and there was nothing.
So I'm a little unsure if I got the full Highmarch battle experience (experience, not XP). When I first had the chance, went out the front gates and held the bridge until most of the Iron Legion was dead, Terry appeared on the parapet and then we could finish them off, including the iLord. Is that how the battle is supposed to look like?
A few asides. As epic and fun as these huge fights are, they do reveal some weaknesses in the game engine and interface. The most aggravating of these was how easy it is to accidentally do friendly fire. When you're left-clicking it isn't too much of a problem because hostile entities are prioritised, but when you want to cast or use a targeted combat move (like IKD, which I use all the time) there is no priority. I had to reload a few times because I angered my allies. That brings me to the next point: as awesome as it looks to hire Azurefang for 300K, his hit box is so ridiculously huge that most everything targeted will default to him. It was fun to do in this first playthrough to see how it looks like, but I do not recommend that anyone do this, it's more a liability than an asset because of the messed up targeting. Unless you use pause, which I don't, and probably then it's still a headache.

Anyway, on to Act 4, dear developers, please never chain a module switch after a long cutscene. I watched that conversation about 10 times because the game would CTD when trying to unpack Act 4/1. I had to reduce resolution to the minimum and temporarily disable my overrides (by renaming the folder) to get to the new module's beginning. The first part was surprisingly short, but showed me how nice it was that I invested in social skills when I managed to avoid a major battle in the desert. By the way, do you ever finally beat the revenant? I fought it 3-4 times in various places but it always said it would rise again. The usefulness of social skills became even more apparent in Part 2 when I thankfully didn't have to kill an old friend. It seems the check difficulties are sometimes modified based on your prior conversation options. For example, when talking to the barbarian shaman, not mentioning that you have been sent by the chief improves your chances a lot.

Is there a bonus for putting out every large fire in the forest areas? I spent quite a bit of time there making sure I got every one (some are way high up in the trees).

Dear developers, never put a serpentine staircase like the one in front of the Inn outside Stoneguard in a module with a party :)

The ranger battle is another one where the weakness of the game engine shows. As far as I can tell, the only aggro control this game knows is proximity aggro, so battles like this become a clusterfakk very quickly, which looks really cool and like the real thing, but can also get annoying. You have to keep the Tusonite commander alive as far as I can tell. I couldn't res him when he died once. I also had to resort to doing the battle alone as especially Maggie would cast creeping doom in the thick of it all, and of course turn all of Tusone hostile :D SoV also has a tendency to hit allies (not your party, though).
Lack of aggro control was also problematic in the Lowmarch final battle, where I believe you have to keep Cadmus (sp?) alive to finish the quest. You can definitely not resurrect the undead. A pity.

Making wizards wear KD immunity items is annoying, but I understand the reason behind it. Mord's and Bigby IX did the trick on Terry (thanks UMD, give them a taste of their own medicine).

The nicest thing about the battle for the capital was Criosa picking the locks to her own house. After the final fight Ronan told me he'd have something for me outside but he never appeared.

I got Epic Dodge right before we went to the Hallway of Very Long, and a few minutes later I could immediately see its usefulness when I had to tank the Emissary of Abaddon or whatever the name of the guy is who comes out of the portal after the Slaad. I should probably not have chosen that doorway as my first, as outside there are quite a few things that don't make sense yet. I do have a little girl following me though, and I got the Überrapier. Also a shield that gives Raksasha magic immunity, among others, which might be a tad overpowered unless they fight with Max IGMS (or 6 Greater Ruins, like a boss in MTS).

The plot overall has been great so far. It is full of plotholes, but then again so are AAA productions (generally my yardsticks being Dragon Age / Mass Effect). Shame on Bioware, this is how the OC's should have looked like instead of the nonsense they churned out :( (Slapping Bioware with their own stick!) The writing has definitely improved throughout the Acts. I generally like plots that involve a zombie apocalypse like this one, because it's an enemy that cannot be argued with and facilitates the union of different factions. Again DA/ME are good examples of how to use the trope well. I enjoy how the story tries to integrate gameplay elements, raise dead being a prime example, and the attempt is laudable, even though it raises more questions than it answers :)

But enough of idle chatter, SCREENSHOTS! The Too Many Adventures of Roxanne With Not Enough Screenshots (hopefully click on them to view in HD):
Exhibit A: The White Furs of Aielund start towards the cold East.


The trademark (also +2CHA).


And the look.

On our way to Highmarch in Act 3.

Snowy mountainscapes are absolutely stunning throughout.

In the capital of Tusone, we set out to do much mischief. You can already see what was to become the All Blacks. Also LACES!

My favourite head model in the game. The plastic surgeon in World of Greyhawk allows you to pick this head in-game which is just another reason to play that awesome PW/module.

The All Blacks set out on an epic quest of picking flowers to save the people of Bracksworth for the I lost count of how manieth time.

Having fun with UMD in the charred forest. Just a pretty face, the merged stats are terrible.

The beautiful young couple.

TBC in the next post, limit reached.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
The Too Many Adventures of Roxanne With Not Enough Screenshots continued:


The invasion about to begin, observed by the latest member-to-be of the All Blacks.
That's it so far!

14. The nicest thing about the battle for the capital was Criosa picking the locks to her own house. After the final fight Ronan told me he'd have something for me outside but he never appeared.

15. I got Epic Dodge right before we went to the Hallway of Very Long, and a few minutes later I could immediately see its usefulness when I had to tank the Emissary of Abaddon or whatever the name of the guy is who comes out of the portal after the Slaad. I should probably not have chosen that doorway as my first, as outside there are quite a few things that don't make sense yet. I do have a little girl following me though, and I got the Überrapier. Also a shield that gives Raksasha magic immunity, among others, which might be a tad overpowered unless they fight with Max IGMS (or 6 Greater Ruins, like a boss in MTS).
Some great shots there Mirnaia, and really pleased you're enjoying it!

It does seem that EE opens some previously unavailable options - having the ability to take more henchies with you would be my guess for the biggest game-changer. I'm still running on steam power here (to be fair, I'm running on air atm - still can't get NwN to play - boo), but I'll try to answer what I can from the version I know...

(Hope you don't mind, but I've numbered points for ease of reference - 'cos there are a few!)

1. Never had a problem accessing any of the areas in the Saqarin base in the desert: and that's without using Search. I can't recall having to retrieve anything specific either (other than the part of the rod, obviously). That said, I don't remember there being a tower in there, so maybe you're talking about somewhere else.)

2. Correct, no point in battling the Iron Lord in Trinity at all. I spent my first few return visits there trying to fight him and failing abysmally before Empyre put me straight on that. When you go to the next screen back north, you do get to help the king out against some nasty legionnaires before going back to the screen just south of Highmarch, but you are being followed.

3. You didn't screw anything up: it all depends on how you want to play. After meeting the rangers over that stone bridge, I tend to leg it with my henchies back to the north of the screen and park them there, then run back down to the rangers, who are by now engaged in a massive battle with the legionnaires following you to Highmarch, along with those things that just ping down from nowhere (can't remember their names atm) and start killing folk. My thinking is that there's a whole field of the buggers coming up, but they're all bottle-necked, so I get loads of xp, which I might lose if I wait for them to get to Highmarch and others kill them. Plus it makes the Battle of Highmarch that much easier, as I believe there's only a finite number of them, and they don't respawn.

4. You do need to leave Highmarch to deal with the mountainous golem who's chucking rocks at the fort, but I then go back inside to await the Ironlord. After beating on him to no avail Terry will appear and do his trick - then I kill the tin bull. And hopefully not everyone else is dead.

5. Might be an EE glitch - I've never experienced that with IKD.

6. I've always killed/had to kill Azurefang outside the Valley of Silence, so wouldn't know. I believe Empyre's Persuasive Archer once brought her along to the battle.

7. Again, I suspect it's an EE issue.

8. You can get loads of sell-able/usable gear from that battle in the desert! I think 3 or 4 revenant deaths is about right. The last time I see him is just when you reach the screen where you need the water for.

9. Alas, I've always had to give battle - and it always hurts me to do so. As to Talon Black Tiger, I know you get better xp from the persuasion route (Empyre's aforementioned build), but you get better gear for a naughty pc/npc if you kill him.

10. While I don't think there's an xp bonus for getting every fire, you do get xp for each one - and if you haven't done enough the Treants won't help you, so...

11. That must be a new addition.

12. All you need do is keep one of the Tuson archers alive - anyone else is a bonus. And how come you've still got Maggie for that encounter? Oh, sorry, more available companions.

13. No, you don't need to keep Cadmus alive to complete the quest - just kill the drow priestess and smash the phylactery. In fact (and tell no one, 'cos I try to play good-aligned characters), if you let him die you can loot him for an excellent sword.

14. Now that's a shame: the cutscene with Ronan and all your previous pals can bring a tear to the eye. I hope that's just a glitch. That said, did you remember to talk to the cat before leaving the palace?

15. That's a perfectly good starting point, but I tend to do it 3rd. I do the frozen realm where you get cut off (Twilight?) first, then Elysium, because there's a bard there who might ask you to fetch her a harp, which is with the chromatic dragon and steal-able (though it might make her cross). As far as the little girl goes...have you found a very injured man, but can't help him because you're ethereal? If so, you might want to seek out a particular pig, then you can show the girl where the man is.

Hope at least some of this is helpful.

Cheers

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
This is great Stag, thank you! I'm also playing NWN 1.69, not EE, just using the latest version of the Saga.

1) I'm pretty sure we're talking about the same thing. It's the golem factory where part of the sceptre is. I guess I haven't missed anything then.
3) I don't recall having a fight there, so I guess i DID screw something up. :) But my memory could be failing too.
4) I didn't go back in after the siege golem, but about 2 minutes after the Ironlord got close to me Terry appeared, and I had plenty of the iLegion to kill in the meantime.
5) Again, I'm playing 1.69. It's not technically a glitch, just an annoyance that it's both easy to accidentally click on an ally and that some creatures' hitboxes are so huge that they obscure pretty much anything else you want to target.
6) Next time I'll just kill A'Fang right at the pass.
7) I'd rather think it's my overrides and shaders eating my PC's memory. Or an undocumented boss fight :D
8) Yeah, at the water pool was the last time I fought it too. Good to know about the sellable equipment, but I made my money back quite quickly, and never really had a shortage of funds except at the very beginning of the Tusonite capital. There I had to consider and prioritise my purchases for a bit.
12) I think Maggie's supposed to say goodbye after you exit the forest, but for me it happened right before I set off to assault the capital (still on the Stoneguard map).
13) Mmmm.
14) Oh, THAT'S what Ronan was referring to. Yeah, I got that cutscene and it was great! I though it would be an in-game conversation. I did talk to the cat, of course :) Worst undercover cat name ever, by the way ;)
15) I finished the Border Ethereal just after I posted, and did manage to get the girl to the sick man. I initially thought you'd have to trigger something in a different world first, but that was not the case.
Thanks for all your points!

I'm now in the lost city in Twilight (second door I've opened), I hope I'll be able to get back to the dragon when I get to that point.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content: And it's all over (all owing to Ironlord IV's noble sacrifice)! Amazing series.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I've learned some new stuff here. I have never had the bard ask for a harp, and I have never had that little girl follow me nor seen that sick man. However, until my last two play-throughs, I was playing a really old version of the Aielund Saga, so I have probably only missed those things twice.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
To round things off, Stag:

3) Yes, I did have the conversation with the Ranger leader about the impending attack, which never came.
8) I don't really spend money on consumables, and I basically never spend any on health pots. I kept/bought a few summon / breach / IGMS / bigby scrolls for getting shite off the fan, and a few Cats which I never needed.
12) I would never… oh wait, I just did.

The definition of "a couple" is an interesting bit. Since I watch a lot of ice hockey, I was suprised to find out that "in Canadian" a couple literally means the number two.

I was not asked to retrieve the harp, probably because I've already been to riddle-land by that point. There is a Perform check there where you tell your adventures to the angel-bard. In addition to the theatre in Act 2, another incentive to play a high level bard.

After struggling through the lost city's uncrittable/unsneakable/untrippable denizens (and I should REALLY have stocked up on darkfire/flame weapon scrolls), Hell and the rest seemed super easy because most things there were susceptible to the above, though they had stellar discipline, a lot eaiser to hit than to knock off their feet. The Saqa(a)rin are all immune to KD but they can be crit, the golems didn't have the AB to really be of concern.

I read somewhere that originally you had 5 minutes on the second floor, instead of the 7 minutes I had. I assume you have to run then (and put your party on peaceful follow) - I had a little less than 2 minutes left out of 7 and I cleared everything, including the big room with the golems and the technicians, before disabling the crystals.

Combat was overall easier yet more gimmicky than I expected (from my readings I was expecting WoG difficulty), but mostly fun and rewarding, with quite a few fights where there were extra tactics required - the (draco)lich fights, for example. There was not a single Time Stop, though (I felt something was off with mage fights, and I just realised what it was). I always play on Hardcore, and I played with the original spell system.

Should (When) I decide to replay the module, I'll try the party-less approach, maybe with the kama-shinobi in Mick's honour, a really fun build, or perhaps with a Cleric/Bard (my two favourite classes) or I'll pick up my Bard/BG4/RDD10 from Act 2. I suppose I'll also have to do it a third time with a male character to see the other romance :D

I really felt I was in a good AAA production, I can hardly begin to imagine the amount of work that went into the module.

Final two screenshots:
Nellise as her true self.

Ironlord and his Rock Band, final tour.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Mirnaia wrote: The definition of "a couple" is an interesting bit. Since I watch a lot of ice hockey, I was suprised to find out that "in Canadian" a couple literally means the number two.

I was not asked to retrieve the harp, probably because I've already been to riddle-land by that point. There is a Perform check there where you tell your adventures to the angel-bard. In addition to the theatre in Act 2, another incentive to play a high level bard.

I read somewhere that originally you had 5 minutes on the second floor, instead of the 7 minutes I had. I assume you have to run then (and put your party on peaceful follow) - I had a little less than 2 minutes left out of 7 and I cleared everything, including the big room with the golems and the technicians, before disabling the crystals.

Should (When) I decide to replay the module, I'll try the party-less approach, maybe with the kama-shinobi in Mick's honour, a really fun build, or perhaps with a Cleric/Bard (my two favourite classes) or I'll pick up my Bard/BG4/RDD10 from Act 2. I suppose I'll also have to do it a third time with a male character to see the other romance :D
Again "a couple" of nice shots! (And technically, in English English "a couple" also means two, whereas "to couple" is a different thing entirely...)

I suspect that harp retrieval is also dependent on the self-same Perform check. I've only had sufficient levels of Bard and Perform twice (active avoidance of the c-word). The theatre quest remains open with only one level of Bard, though a peaceful resolution may only be possible with more.

Yes, that timer can be quite a tight squeeze (I'm on the earlier setting). And for once, it means it. If you're timed out (happened to me more than once), you go to a cutscene of Fairloch which shows everyone dying, and that's the end. So it really is a matter of just getting the job done - you can have a look around afterwards. I think that's a classy touch - it ain't often you're shown what happens when you fail in these games.

I don't know about you, but I found the latter stages of Part 4 somewhat frustrating in terms of story-arc. It all gets a little OTT once the Hall of Worlds opens up. More combat variety, maybe, but a bit...deflating. Still, I can't think of many games where the destination lives up to the journey (so, pretty much true to life, then).

In a replay, maybe rather than just soloing, try it with fewer henchies? I think they bring flavour. And yes, Mick's Kama-Shinobi is excellent - the only evil build I've ever successfully played - and in Aielund to boot! Oh, and yes, playing a male character will give a different dimension to Criosa's situation.

Glad you had a good time!

Cheers

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
It may cause less stress to know that the timer in act 4-3 stops once you have destroyed the power plant and the crystals. That can be important if you solo a build where things can take a little longer to kill. Just rush through and get that job done first. After destroying the crystals you have all the time in the world to clear the floor of everything.

Oh, and when I have a couple of beers, two is just a number.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote:I am on yet another solo run.
This time I play a mage; The Evil Speed Caster - Sorcerer35/ Monk3/ Blackguard2.
So I finished this one on thursday. This character also ended at lvl 38. Soloing as a sorcerer/ monk was very different from playing a fighter, archer or rogue.
You easily get a "glass cannon" feeling. Without your buffs, you are so vulnerable. And at your best you can kill a whole crowd with a single spell.
As for the speed effect, it worked well enouth to equip a haste item, for the extra action per round, and add to the speed with one or two castings of extended expeditious retreat!
And it really helps to know what the spells do:
Spoiler In act 4, part 3 at one point you have to fight slaads and after that a single disciple of Abbadon together with another mage before you can enter a portal. I tried to do that with death-  and evocation spells and was completely out of spells after the fight. The slaad had high fort saves and the disciple of Abbadon was immine to death magic. Only after the fight did I realize that I should have used the Banishment spell, since they are all outsiders.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
Now that we saw some Aielund build requests, for the record, let me post my rogue that I did the module with (you can find my after action reports a few pages back in the thread.) It's a customisation of Maximillian Kane's Drow Fencer that we know and love.
The really cool thing about her is that she maxes out all three social skills and still feels very complete, in addition to being amazing in melee and a decent shot. Set trap did have to go out the window, but notice that Disable is still going strong. At the end, with capped Dex, you can take 20-disarm a DC58 trap.
Lore at the end can be anything, and there are so many skill priorities that you can swap them around quite a bit. The one below worked for me. Keep a CHA + social skills item set for conversations. Your conversation options can very much influence the DC's of the checks, it's done intelligently.
I have looked at many builds to take Bluff/Intimidate/Persuade with (and at least 21 Search for a first playthrough) and still not have to compromise too much. Sorcerers (for insane charisma), bards, rogues, wizards, even paladins/bg's for crying out loud, and all kinds of their combinations, but this is the only one where it worked out for me. Watch out for true seeing casters! (Watch out for any caster until your AB kicks in.) You're very tanky even with 8 CON, but you're no Epic Brawler Champion. You're a rogue, do it from behind!

Dame Roxanne, leader of The White Furs of Bracksworth, founder of The All Blacks, keyboard player and vocalist of Ironlord and his Rock Band (there are screenshots for all of these back in the thread)

posts.author: MentalDekay
posts.content:
Hey all! Long time stalker first time talker..

Anywho, I'm in the middle of my first (to be completed) play thru (about to leave for Highmarch in Act 3) using an Exalted Sorcerer. I've played with all the companions I could to experience as much of the dialogue as possible (tho I ditched Spartan fairly quickly because he got in the way of every door, enemy or npc and cuz he's worse than the princess at charging into fights).

I really like the module and I'm already thinking about future runs. To that end, I was wondering if I could get several recommendations for toons that facilitate different alignments (not just the goody two shoes), possible solo, and buffing that takes less than 20% of every session. My first thoughts were a monk/shifter or rogue/wm. An all-in-one build would be ok, but a couple of suggestions that fit one or two if those traits would be fine as I expect tho play again multiple times.

If it matters, I'm playing EE on an LG V40 because I can fire it up over lunch.

Thanks in advance!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hi MentalDekay!

RE being evil. I've finished Aielund with an evil character. he did a lot of buffing which I guess is not what you want. Being evil, you miss out on a few perks but it is super enjoyable still, especially if you keep Nelise in your party for some evil - good dialog. She is a total angel for enduring my evil character and his evil ways (I think there are only two actions that she will not tolerate and will leave - I heard whispers Savant created an 'evil cleric' companion to replace her if you choose a certain option in Act 4 part 3 but I never accessed this). 

Parts of the end of the last module you will find every enemy has true sight, is knockdown immune and sneak immune (not sure about crit immune too), if that helps with your build design...
I can't help much with monk/shifter or rogue/wm builds. The  ECB filter or the ECB archives might have some builds that look good to you. Some of the others will do better with suggestions with those class combos than me

Hope it helps

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Aielund is great for unarmed Monks, either STR-based or DEX-based, or katana-wielding WMs or RDDs.  I have played all of those in Aielund, but never evil.  I can post any or all of those builds, if you want them.  I probably have already posted them earlier in this thread.

There are areas in Chapter 2 where you would miss having a Rogue with you, unless you have high Rogue skills yourself.

It's counter to how I usually play, but having played this much of the module I expect savant probably does have some good evil (?) moments ready to be found.

Empyre,

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello and welcome, Mental Dekay (not a sentence I ever thought I would say).

Until Empyre comes back, here are a couple of evil builds for you. Both are Mick Dagger's (unsurprisingly), and I know he's played both through solo. The second remains the only evil build I've successfully played - though I didn't solo it.

Evil Speed Caster

Kama-Shinobi

Aielund remains my favourite module: for the story and quality of the NPCs as much as anything (and do try it with different genders). It's perfectly playable as just about any decent build and stands up well to replaying. If I understand right, EE allows you to take up to 3 companions, which one could argue is a good thing, but I like the discipline of keeping it to 2, and all have their merits.

I'll shut up now, else I'll prattle on forever.

Cheers

EDIT: Ninja'd by Empyre!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I like all these builds. hard to choose from all of them. I have EE. I was able to get 4 companions in act 2  (Sir Bryce-Clifton, Valennia, Maggie and Ronan)  during my Paladin/Blackguard playthrough - I took Bryce when I was 'good' then became evil, I'm sure part of Act 4 part 2 with my evil backstabby cleric/blackguard/monk I had 4 companions
Spoiler (Criosa/Nelise/Maggie/Ronan) - I think there was a script that failed to activate to make Maggie leave. 
Having a lot of party members did dilute exp gain but it didn't really affect gameplay that much, like I got to level 36 which is pretty good
by the way agree completely with MD its a lovely module, probably the best single player module I have every played... out of curiousity - the non EE NWN players out there -> is Aielund stable? my NWN EE crashed heaps, like a lot of transitions or sometimes even saving the game I just spammed my quick and vanilla save game function constantly just in case throughout that module

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
While Aielund is fun to play over and over, I highly recommend that you play something else in between, like SoU+The Nether Scrolls(fun but optional)+HotU+Sands of Fate, or the OC + Mines of Twin Summit, or Lord of Terror, or Eye of the Beholder, or the Adam Miller campaign (Shadowlord, Dreamcatcher, and Demon), or Saleron's Gambit, etc.  It would be a shame to get tired of Aielund.

Having henchmen will reduce the XP per kill, but the number of enemies increases to make up for it.

In NWN 1.69, Aielund is about as stable as other modules.  Crashes are rare, but they do happen.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote: In NWN 1.69, Aielund is about as stable as other modules.  Crashes are rare, but they do happen.
Tempted to get the non-EE version of NWN just for the stability! Doesn't look easy to find

posts.author: MentalDekay
posts.content:
NWN:EE has crashed for me a handful of times (Android 9, QCM 845, 6GB RAM) while playing Aielund. A couple weeks ago I spent an hour playing where everybody had literally lost their heads. I think my issues are probably due to switching between apps, prolonged app uptime, etc leading to some corrupted memory. No real complaints otherwise (beyond the ~2mm tall letters). I seem to remember Lilura and Savant talking on some forum* about the module and EE, first guess is at Beamdog's site. Looking through my phone's NWN directory, I counted about 70 crash log files. Apparently the issues are more common than I have noticed. I can't say how much is from playing Aielund however. 

I've never played thru Swordflight, so that's on the to-do list. And while I've went OC + HOU, I haven't added on with other modules. Yet. Past me's have played Adam's adventures for NWN2. My phone is full with Beamdog and Square Enix products so I'll have to drop things if I want to add other substantial modules/games. Plus, I don't want to get squirreled when I'm so close to actually completing a significant play through.

Feel free to prattle Stag (or anyone else) I'm obviously into the conversation.

The main goal for my next toon will probably be minimal buffing, whichever module I play. I'm undecided on LE/NE/CE/CN. The Kama-Shinobi and Evil Speed Caster look like good LE options. Tho one of Empyre's katana crazos might make a good CE/CN natural disaster.

* On that note, are there other forums that go as deep into toon-ology for BG's and IWD? Y'all are almost as sick as those CivFanatics folks. I know there's the nwn2db, just wondering if the others had forums with the same depth of analysis.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
By toon-ology, you mean character builds for BG/IWD?

If so, you can try the "official" Beamdog forums, before that, scan them through Google, as Orion showed for getting directly to what you want instead of searching endlessly. 

But I'm gonna do one better than that, in fact I'll show you on action some powerful builds in a "very, very tough" environment.

Here is a guy that I found a year or so ago, that makes a whole playthrough of Bg1 TotsC & Bg2 SoA-ToB, with the "sword coast stratagems" mod installed & his main(s) are both Kensai ladies.

He is a master at what he does.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
For crying out loud Mental Dekay, don't give me license to prattle on, I'm bad enough as it is! People will start thinking one of us is Noober!

To look at the Aielund-specific stuff first (given that it's the name of thread and all), I'll be less use than a chocolate fireguard on the techy elements. However, I believe Savant released an Aielund update called "Enhanced Edition" mere months - if not only weeks - before Beamdog's EE. This, of course, was not in the least confusing . The Aielund-specific EE was (and still is, afaik) 1.69-friendly, so can be used in "normal" NwN games and shouldn't suffer from Beamdog's "teething troubles" (you won't be surprised to learn that we have a thread about EE, too, upon which I also get a bit mouthy). And that's all I know about that.

Before I go look at Valerfor's vid, can I also commend to you Empyre's Persuasive Archer (he's posted it here on page 7, I think, so it's not hard to find - what the hell, read it all!) for a different take that seems to have worked well.

Right, time for a bit of a BG hit...

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
It's not about relying on, your party - Aielund's about the only module where it's simply a joy to have them along for the ride. And it helps that the AI means they're not complete idiots when it does come to combat. However, feel free to park them up wherever you feel like - I'm certainly not suggesting you take a sub-par build. Just remember to pick them up again and have a little chat afterwards. Challenging yourself is splendid, but actually having a laugh in the middle of something is priceless.

And of course, I know you've done it before, Mick, and will do so again. But I can't think you'll ever regret travelling with Maggie in chapter 2, or Bobby Black in chapter 3, even if only for the conversations. You end up actually believing in the world through which you play, not just a personal challenge. Or fun, as it might otherwise be known!

But if you do want to play a completely nerfed character, how about The Scholar ? Just a thought...

Enjoy, my friend!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I know what you mean Stag. I used to play the series the way you suggest. I am not foreign to party roleplay on PWs either. The solo play was just something I have done to challenge some builds and how they can be played. I found that the stalker type assassin actually benefits from being played this way, something I also write in my assassin guide. Another point is that many people play on PWs  with few other players of the same level. So it is good to know how you can manage with a build on its own.

As for the Scholar build, I did actually try it in a party with miss Nellise and mr Colt.  I soon gave up. Not because it was hard to make any progress, but because it was a pain to force myself to follow the terrible schedule at every level-up.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
The Aielund katanas are reverting to act like normal NWN katanas in NWN:EE.  I just checked, and it is doing that in 1.69, too.  Savant has been aware of this since April, but apparently hasn't had time to fix it because he is so busy with other projects, like publishing a series of novels based on the Aielund Saga and a tabletop game.

There are some pretty cool katanas in the Aielund Saga, so focusing on the katana is still not a total waste.  Meanwhile, in addition to the kukri, the rapier also has 18-20 crits, and there are some nice rapiers in the game, too.  I usually reserve rapiers for Criosa and/or Ronan (the rogue hench in Act 2, whose name I might remember wrong), but you can use them yourself and give them something else.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
@Dingpot - You can't kill the Ironlord until Terry turns up (without cheating) - that was the whole point of grabbing the various bits of the rod and giving them to him. Otherwise it's like trying to take him down in Trinity - not gonna happen.

One tip that does work is to run away. And then run away some more. Basically, grab your team (if you're travelling with henchies) and run around a lot once the boss has entered the keep, preferably pulling him after you so he doesn't kill all your allies en route - assuming you're playing a good guy, of course. When Terry pops up, turn around and finish the tin minotaur off.

Hope this both helps and gives you heart that you weren't doing anything wrong!

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Oh, and as for his army, if you want to hog all the xp and kill the lot of 'em (well, the war golems, anyway, not those irritating buggers who ping in from nowhere) before they reach the keep, on the previous screen, after you've spoken with the rangers near the bridge, run up to the top of the screen and park your henchies (they'll only get in the way). Then leg it back to that bridge on your own.

The poor rangers don't last long, but now you have a perfect choke-point. Only one of them can cross at a time, so simply despatch 'em one at a time. They're not respawning, but you might get a bit bored 'cause there are about 30 of them. When no more seem to be coming (iirc they turn up in 3s), run back and pick up your friends, then on the keep.

That way you'll only have to deal with that mahussive one outside the gates, as many of the aforementioned irritating buggers as you can be bothered with, and the boss himself inside the keep - a lot less clutter!

Cheers

posts.author: Crispysuns
posts.content: How often do dialogue checks appear in Aielund Saga? Is bluff or persuade useful?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Crispysuns wrote: ↑
Apr 03, 2021
How often do dialogue checks appear in Aielund Saga? Is bluff or persuade useful? 
Hello again, Crispysuns!

First let me say I'm delighted you're giving Aielund a run - it remains my favourite story-based module by a country mile, and its scope is vast.

As to whether Bluff and Persuade are worthwhile, I'd say Persuade definitely is. I can't say I've ever really tried Bluff, so wouldn't like to raise/lower expectations there. From Empyre's recounting of his Persuasive Archer build's adventures in the kingdom (earlier in this thread), it's fair to say that Persuade can completely change the outcome of certain events - without hampering xp gains or loot.

As ever, a lot will depend on how many skill points you have at your disposal after allocating primary ones, which will be determined by the type of build you're playing, but the social skills are definitely worth it if you can afford them. Even Intimidate gets some love if you invest enough in it.

Just because I'm nosy, what sort of character are you looking to play?

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Oh, many more playthroughs only enrich the experience! Different classes attract different quests (none plot-critical), as do different henchies - and indeed different genders have an impact. In pure gaming terms, trying different toons helps you with different play-styles, and, of course, going solo will boost your xp (I know Mick's gone to level 38 a couple of times). However, I'm firmly of the view that one plays Aielund for the story and the companionship/ flavour the various henchies lend to the tale - few and far between are other modules that can make me laugh and cry.

Others will doubtless differ, but I'm always in it for the ride, not the end. Probably not the best advert for power-gaming, but still...

Cheers

Barbarian can work very well, as can Ranger (DEX or STR - but don't forget, if you're using one of the ECB Guild builds, Aielund-specific stuff means you'll get an extra 2 skill points per level, like Bard does, so it might be worth thinking about how best to use them in advance). posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: SpoilerIf you play Aielund (or any other module) with EMS there are several changes to the Bard class: You get Weapon Proficiency Rogue. You get 6 skill points per level + int bonus (x4 at lvl 1) You have the following extra spells to choose from: Banishment as C5 Dominate Monster as C6 Endurance as C2 Freedom Of Movement as C4 Greater Shadow Conjuration as C5 Mass Charm as C6 Ray Of Frost as C0 Shadow Conjuration as C4 Stoneskin as C4 The Bard song and Curse song  are changed: Every 6 levels starting at Bard 1: +1 AB, +1 Damage (Bard 1, 7, 13, 19, 25 etc) Every 6 levels starting at Bard 3: +1 Fort Every 6 levels starting at Bard 5: +1 Reflex There is no level 30 song cap At lvl 16 the bonus is: +3 AB, +3 Damage, +3 AC, +3 Fort, +3 Will, +2 Refl, +2 skills, +12 HP, and there is not a clearly defined "Sweet spot" at lvl 16 anymore. Lasting Impression is only 2x normal song duration (i.e. 20 rounds)

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: I have also tested several build ideas up to level 10 by completing act 1 solo.

posts.author: trivialrealities
posts.content: So, a friend of mine is coming back to NWN after a long time, and after them completing a warm-up run through SoU, we're looking to run running something together in co-op. Given how they've never played Aielund before, I suggested we give it a shot. The issue is that we're not exactly sure what characters to play! My friend typically prefers to play arcane casters, and I've never run one through Aielund before so I don't exactly know what to suggest. As for myself, I'd really just like to cover my friend's weaknesses - so probably something frontline, maybe with some trap handling skills. Maybe something along the lines of Empyre's Rough and Ready Rogue, or the Aielund-specific take on the Dwarven Wall he presented here. But any suggestions or ideas are welcome!

My friend typically prefers to play arcane casters, and I've never run one through Aielund before so I don't exactly know what to suggest. As for myself, I'd really just like to cover my friend's weaknesses - so probably something frontline, maybe with some trap handling skills. Maybe something along the lines of Empyre's Rough and Ready Rogue, or the Aielund-specific take on the Dwarven Wall he presented here. But any suggestions or ideas are welcome!
If you want to do a little bit of everything, I'd suggest something like my Yoshimo build. It has it all and then some more in terms of versatility and makes for a hell of a frontliner. As for your friend, ask him what he wants to play, and then send it here for us to be able to offer better help. Dedicated arcane casters may not be as strong in Aielund, though, as monsters have a lot of HP.

Cheers!

posts.author: trivialrealities
posts.content: After some further discussion with them, they're open to the idea of a Sorc/Pld/RDD gish build along the lines of Mick Dagger's Spellsword of Bahamut, albeit maybe with some more Persuade to get more out of Aielund's dialogue. This reduces the need for another frontliner, so maybe something more controlling or supporting for myself?

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
My experience from playing several sorcerers is that arcane casters do very well in the Aielund saga, with or even without a party.
Beware though, that Aielund uses the EMS hak that changes how many spells work. It is different, but still very potent.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Quick question - will it be just the 2 of you, or are you planning on picking up any companions on the way? I ask primarily because if you're travelling with others, you'll have decent trapsmiths available from Chapter 2 onwards (around level 8/9), so investing in Rogue becomes less important. AA works well, and there are several excellent ones in the Full Epic forum. You might also look for a build with Blind Fight and KD, as Mick's spellsword has neither (still an excellent build, however). A Bard is also a good option.

Still, lots of different types can flourish in Aielund, so long as you remember you'll be finishing at around level 36/37 and that Dev Crit is not supported.

Cheers

If you want something indecently powerful and already have a frontliner, I would suggest my Sehanine's Finest build. A very potent archer build that combines the uberness of AA AB and damage bonus with Clerical buffing capabilities (which you can use for both you and your mate). posts.author: trivialrealities
posts.content: How do people feel a rogue/monk-centric Dexer build along the lines of Arvoreen's Silent Sting would work in Aielund, if it was retooled to focus on using the excellent monk gloves, given the dearth of solid kamas?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
You're going to have to grab a melee weapon focus in order to take CoT levels, but re-examining my (with considerable guidance) Silent Sting, you could do that with a fist focus easily, because you wouldn't need the dual-wielding feats - in fact you have 2 more pre-epic feats at your disposal. Just be aware that hin (or gnome) fists only do 2d6 damage with fists, not d20 - and that's at Monk level 16, considerably less beforehand. So, you might have to do a whole levelling remix if you're going for a fist focus. Theoretically, you could go for a WF in both and only have a single weapon (there's a size penalty for dual-wielding kamas), thus still giving you a "spare" couple of feats.

EDIT: If it's an unarmed-focused Monk dexer you're after, you could have a look at Truesilver's Hand. It's a Monk 30/ DwD 5/ SD 5 dwarf, so gets the d20 fists. Your decision, obviously.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Ooh, you've given me another one of your monks to take for a run!

Just one question: is there a particular reason for taking the Fighter levels so late? I can see the rush for Monk 16 - did you simply reckon WS was worth less than d20 fists? Whatever, I like them!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Yes, it is a race to Monk 16.  The average difference between d12 and d20 is 4, which is bigger than the +2 difference from WS.  Also, you get other Monk goodies, such as Monk Speed, spell resistance, and immunity to disease and poison, ASAP.

Thanks for build, I am playing your RDD Katana fighter. I just wonder - should I upgrade my +3 Katana in Act 2 ? Each upgrade cost 30k, Is it worth it to burn all my money?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I'd hang fire - you'll come across at least 2 better ones on your travels, and one of them is probably the best blade in the whole saga (only if you've focused in katana, obviously).

EDIT: Now I think about it, there are at least 4. There's Diamond Edge (+3), Four Stars Circling Heaven (+4), The Wind and the Rain that Falls (+4), and Blackened Skies, Burning Rain (+8 - obviously only available in late game). All have interesting extras thrown in for good measure.

He's in the inn in the town - he needed somewhere to go after the dragon nicked his throne-room after all. He should have given you the quest, actually. Don't know if that has any bearing on things.

No point in hoarding any gold, you won't need it for what Empyre has in mind*. It's basic crafting from stuff you find in a ruined temple in the desert, and the game will point you at what you need to do.
SpoilerYou won't have any gold in any case. There's a classic "have all your gear and money taken from you"  scenario at the start of Act 4. You'll be able to buy some of it back from a trader in Trinity later on, if you still need it by then. But you'll have other things to deal with first.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Persuasion, Bluff, and Intimidate are all useful, but good scores are not guarantees that you will always win those checks.  When I played Aielund with the Persuasive Archer, there were times when it was difficult to keep my henchmen alive, so save often.

@Stag, to link to a specific post in a thread, right-click the post number and select Copy Link.   For example, your post #557 just above mine gives this link:

posts.author: BrodersenPrime
posts.content:
Hi guys,

I just recently got back into nwn. I'm usually bouncing back and forth between either Baldurs Gate or nwn - and only Aielund and Swordflight really provide that epic story i love from the BG series as well.
I am already in the 4th act with Valerfors awesome Moghedien build, but my restartitis is starting to show its ugly head and I am wondering if anyone has had tried a shapeshifting type build in Aielund? I imagine the dragon shape wont really be available untill the very end, but the other shapes may be worth investigating as well. I tried to search the forums and found a lot of shifters, but they seem to all be late bloomers.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
BrodersenPrime wrote: ↑
Oct 15, 2024
Hi guys,

...my restartitis is starting to show its ugly head and I am wondering if anyone has had tried a shapeshifting type build in Aielund? I imagine the dragon shape wont really be available untill the very end, but the other shapes may be worth investigating as well. I tried to search the forums and found a lot of shifters, but they seem to all be late bloomers.

Thanks :)
Typical Dragon Shape is gonna come at level 33 but there is one that comes at level 28 for the impatient ;)
Nature's Wyrm by Kail => https://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/bui ... 28407.html

If you want something different & one that fits through the door, you might want a Risen Lord focused build or a Commando. Ideally, for a Risen Lord, you want a DD build with either 18 or 22 DD levels & EDR 3 too. Think with 24 DR/- plus 50% immunity to slashing/piercing (plus a greater belt of bludgeoning for covering all three melee types) your opponent will have to inflict 49 Dmg with a normal hit to register... 1 Dmg to you! Of course, you'll be immune to WMs & sneak attackers too. Early Risen Lord shape comes at level 24 If I'm not mistaken (Druid 7/ Shifter 11/ DD 22) with level 27 being more typical.

Here's a build from the old ECB Vault => https://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/bui ... 48890.html
Terrifying Risen Lord by Skeleton Pope => risen-lord-barbarian-24-shifter10-druid ... 55722.html

Finally, there's Yip, Yip, You're Dead! That's a monster Kobold with sneak attack, death attack & dev crit, & 73 stealth for good measure
Mick's build => yip-yip-you-re-dead-druid-6-shifter-7-a ... 55014.html

Pan Draconis has his own Commando with Terrifying Rage, which is worth checking out as well
Pan Draconis build => glushshakh-shaman-of-gruumsh-and-kurtul ... 56042.html

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: If you play at Normal skill level, allies' spells cannot adversely affect you.

posts.author: BrodersenPrime
posts.content:
Wow, thats great input guys - thank you! :)

So many builds to chose from... I'm sure a RL build with decent DR and a ton of regen on equipment will prove very hard to kill. Do you know if the vampiric regen of the RL scythe stacks if I have another weapon equipped with say +5 vamp regen?

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Afaik, vamp regen does not stack, so it will most likely just take the highest value - I stand corrected : https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Talk:Regeneration:_vampiric

They don't actually "stack", but it will put multiple instances of the Vampiric Regen on your RL at the different values, and it will randomly select between them when it procs.

I don't know how Aelund handles this, however.
